question:
Ate here yesterday, had some good lunch at good $$. Saw my friend that works here, made some good business calls, talk business with my friend.
Free Wi-Fi is always nice. 
Had a good and productive hour.
I like Sir Hobos.
I will come back.
rationale: The text expresses positive emotion by describing a satisfying lunch, successful business calls, and a productive hour spent at the restaurant with free Wi-Fi, highlighting an overall pleasant experience that the writer enjoyed and plans to repeat in the future. Predicted Emotion: Positive

question:
Blech.  My brother heard this was the best Chinese buffet in Sun Prairie.  Maybe that is true, but it must be the only Chinese buffet in Sun Prairie.

I'm not giving it a hard time for "authenticity" or any of that eaither.  I love me some good Americanized, crappy Chinese food.  Here, even the stuff that was out fresh from the kitchen (which was mighty slim picken's) was barely edible.

I was really looking forward to some good old MIdwestern Chinese buffet, too.  The Chinese food options in Portland are actually very lacking, the last really good stuff I had was from a strip mall in Crawfordsville, IN.  Seriously, they can do it right but everyone else serves lukewarm, tasteless piles of mystery?  Gotta be kidding me.

Most options seemed to have been sitting for way too long when we got here, and it was peak dinner eating time.  I should have been tipped off by the low number of patrons at this "best Chinese" but I like to give the benefit of the doubt.

You are better off making Ramen noodles at home and calling it chinese food.
rationale: The review expresses negative emotion through disappointment with the quality and taste of the food, as well as frustration with the lack of fresh options and the overall dining experience.

question: closed.
rationale: The text uses the word "closed" which implies a sense of finality, limitation, or restriction, leading to a feeling of negativity or disappointment. Predicted emotion: negative sentiment. Rationale: The word "closed" often conveys a sense of exclusion, ending or lack of access, which can lead to feelings of disappointment or frustration.

question: Good old fashioned diner food with a generous all you can eat prime rib and butterfly shrimp on Saturdays.
rationale: The text praises traditional diner food and highlights the appeal of all-you-can-eat prime rib and butterfly shrimp on Saturdays, indicating a positive sentiment towards the experience of dining at the restaurant. Predicted emotion: Positive.

question: Best breakfast in town. One of those great old-school diners that knows how to make a good meal and make you feel at home. The prices are also some of the best I've ever seen for the awesome quality. I recommend the Greek omelette.
rationale: The text mentions various positive aspects such as the great food quality, affordable prices, and welcoming atmosphere, which would likely make the reader feel satisfied and happy, predicting a positive emotion.

question: I'm not sure what all the rave reviews for this place are about. Some of the food was decent like the bacon deluxe omelette; but the service was slow and the waffle was served cold.  Also, when I originally ordered the quiche Lorraine I was told it would be another 10 minutes before it would be done, but there was a piece of the veggie quiche available, so I ordered the veggie quiche and  we still waited almost 30 minutes to get our food!!!! You should never have to wait that long at a diner!! If you like fake, half melted cheese, cold waffles, slow service and supporting a small local business go here. If you want good food, more of a variety, faster service and less expensive for what you get, go somewhere else.
rationale: The review highlights several negative aspects of the dining experience, such as slow service, cold food, and long wait times, along with expressing disappointment with the quality of the food. Thus, it shows negative emotion. Predicted emotion: Disappointment.

question:
called to order flowers and explain that i would be overnighting a card to go with them.  when i asked annie if it would be ok to include cash instead of givIng cc# (as long as i was shipping a card there) was told "that's really a stupid idea"  i explained that there are some intelligent people who believe that giving a cc# out is a bigger risk than losing $70 cash.  

called the owner dina the next day to give her some feedback as a fellow business owner. she told me "annie would never say that."  

been a long time since i've been called stupid and a longer time since i've been called a liar.  rude, inconsiderate, and most definitely not customer service oriented.  i rarely write negative reviews, but stay away is my advice.
rationale: The review shows negative emotion as the customer experienced rudeness, inconsideration, and poor customer service, leading them to advise others to stay away from the business. Predicted sentiment: Negative.

question: Great shop! They did my flowers for prom, and I was super satisfied. Awesome customer service, affordable for high school students, and they really support local causes. I would totally recommend.
rationale: This review is positive because the author expresses satisfaction with the shop's service, affordability for high school students, and support for local causes, leading to a recommendation, indicating a positive sentiment.

question: We went to this store at 8 pm they close at 10pm they were out of dark meat in crispy, they had no mac and cheese made.  they did let us get some extra chicken because we wanted three sides of mac and cheese.  The people who woked here tried very hard but just didnt seem to know what was going on.  We went in for two 10 peice buckets and it took us more then a half hour to get what we needed..  this is the second time we had been there and the service was terrible both times.
rationale: The review depicts a negative emotion as it highlights dissatisfaction with the lack of available menu items, confusion among staff, long wait times, and overall poor service during multiple visits to the store. Predicted sentiment: Negative emotion.

question: The last time I went in there I observed: cross contamination, unfriendly service(no two part greeting), dirty rag BUCKETS left ON THE COUNTER where they set the tongs for serving food, no hand washing by employees, and confusion with my order although it was a simple one consisting of 12 strips.\nAlso, another customer came in while I was waiting and asked if they could prioritize her order because she was in a hurry. They said yes, but it resulted in a lot of confusion between employees which drastically slowed service time. The customer complained about the wait, which resulted in an indifferent response from a employee. He said \"if you wanted your order faster you should have called it in\". He said this with an attitude. Then he turned to me and asked if I thought he handled that correctly, and I said no. \nIn the end, being a former employee of this establishment, I was very disappointed with the cleanliness and customer service.
rationale: The review expresses a negative sentiment due to the various instances of poor customer service, lack of cleanliness, and overall disappointment with the experience at the establishment.

question: This location does not have good service. Went through drive-through and they forgot our drinks and our sides. While they were preparing what they forgot, we could see another girl who had her back to us and it was obvious that she was on her phone. Any other KFC would be better.
rationale: The review expresses negative emotions by detailing a disappointing experience with poor service at a specific KFC location, including missing items, unprofessional behavior by staff members, and a comparison to other KFC branches as being superior, indicating dissatisfaction and frustration. Predicted emotion: Negative.

question: The most family oriented work out place in town.  We love the indoor family and warm water pools. The nursery staff is excellent. I like that when we come in to drop the kids off at the nursery, they greet us by our first names.  I love the infrared sauna they recently put in. \nOne advice I would give to people who are considering of joining is that you don't have to get the most exclusive membership like gold cove, if you are only going to work out on the machines. We have gold cove, the most expensive membership which allows you to have exclusive access to outdoor water park during summer and most of the group fitness classes offered in the club but we hardly go to group fitness class and hardly go to outdoor water park. The water temperature is still cold even it is 80 degrees out. This past summer, we went to the outdoor water park maybe two- three times the most and stayed out no more than half hour. So, it really isn't worth to have a gold cove unless you know you are looking for specific classes with GC membership. \nThe parking and getting the machine to work out can be a problematic during winter months between 4:30-7:00PM. Sometime, you may have to wait 15-20 minutes for the machine to free. If that's the case, you can go sit in the sauna until some people leave. So, I would suggest go there early in the morning or late in the evening but then if you are bringing along your little ones you run into problems with daycare after nursery is closed. They have a restaurant that offers supposedly healthier food but we never had any luck with the food there. The taste is okay and price is a little bit on the high end for the amount you get.
rationale: The review mentions positive aspects such as family-oriented facilities, excellent nursery staff, and the addition of an infrared sauna, but also highlights issues like cold water in the outdoor park and difficulty finding available machines during peak hours, leading to a mixed sentiment leaning towards negative due to the dissatisfaction with certain features and services provided.

question: If you want to sweat, exercise, and have fun they have it all.  They have free weights, universal machines, treadmills, stair climbers, elliptical machines, bikes, a running track, basketball courts, volleyball courts, an indoor soccer field, an indoor pool and outdoor water park, aerobic classes, massage services, personal trainers, racquetball courts, a conference room, a full service bar, a flat grill menu, and probably much more.
rationale: The text lists a wide range of amenities and services available at the fitness center, indicating a positive and enthusiastic tone towards the variety of options provided for exercise and relaxation, leading to a positive sentiment of excitement or satisfaction.

question: The TV reception is absolutely horrible. I have emailed Prairie athletic club a couple times in regards to the situation. Both the new and the older treadmills and elliptical's all have horrible reception. The brand new ellipticals still need to be leveled out so they do not rock. Plan on bringing your iPod with headphones because even the new ellipticals headphone connections do not work.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as it highlights multiple issues with the TV reception, equipment functioning, and customer service at the Prairie athletic club, ultimately suggesting a frustrating and disappointing experience for the reader.

question:
I've been convinced to re-write my review for this particular Walmart.  

The previous review I wrote was pretty bad.  So allow me to begin again.

This Walmart location is one of the teeny tiny, original designs.  The parking lot has so many huge dips and holes I sometimes think I am being forced to go spelunking in my car.  

The old lady greeters at the front door are my favorite part of the experience because they remind me of grandma.  But they would probably mace me if I tried to run up and give them a hug.  

They have a fabric department, which seems to be a feature that the newer, super walmarts are missing.  Unfortunately, the store is usually running a skeleton crew most of the time, so it's hard to find an employee in that section of the store who knows how to cut some fabric.  

Most of the employees here are like most of the employees at any Walmart, underpaid, and overworked.  So it doesn't bother me too much when they frown at me.  I've been on the other side of the register before, so I know how soul crushing it can be.  Though, they may not be frowning at me because of that reason, they probably just know I'm an incredible dufus.  

However, there is one employee there who is usually cashiering, and has this wonderful Russian accent.  She's also very friendly and cheery.  The other day she was telling me about growing her own basil, freezing it in ice cube trays with chicken stock, and then plopping the cubes in rice later on for flavoring.  Tricky, tricky!  

Anyway, I guess I am more impressed by the larger Walmart in Monona that has the shopping cart escalators.  I could stand there all day and launch carts down that thing, it really revs up the dork in me.  

But in the meantime, if I don't feel like heading over that way I could just stop at this Walmart to get maced by the grannies and listen to cooking recipes from Nina.
rationale: The text shows a mix of positive and negative emotions. Positive aspects include the reminiscing about the old lady greeters and the friendly cashier with the Russian accent, while negative aspects include the difficulties with the parking lot, lack of employees, and feeling underappreciated by some staff members. Predicted sentiment: Neutral.

question: It is a walmart so i never expect much but i think this is the smallest walmart i have ever seen! the selection was slim to non. and the school supplies were all over the store.  I dont think that i would ever go back to this store! the cashiers were very slow and the managment semi unapproachable!
rationale: This review expresses negative emotion because the customer was disappointed with the small selection, disorganization, slow checkout experience, and unapproachable management at the Walmart, leading them to decide not to return in the future. Predicted sentiment: Negative.

question:
I live in Sun Prairie, but I drive to the east side of Madison Wal-mart instead of using this one about half the time. This store is SMALL. And OLD. In a word: dingy. 

It does have a fabric department (as does the east side Madison store), which is better than that giant thing in Monona (though that has underground parking, which I love). The employees at this location vary from indifferent to pretty helpful. The cashiers are mostly the former. Having done that exact job, I can relate.  

They have a couple of small aisles with food stuffs (bread, cereal) and there are coolers in the front with milk and OJ, which is wonderful when all you need is some cheap fabric, a gallon of milk, and a tube of mascara. 

There are plans to build a new Wal-Mart right behind this one, then demolish this one and turn it into parking lot. I am waiting with baited breath.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the author highlights the small, old, and dingy nature of the store, as well as the indifferent and unhelpful behavior of some employees. The anticipation for a new Walmart to be built and the current store to be demolished also suggests a lack of satisfaction with the current location.

question:
This is a brand-new Walmart that was built right next to the old one. They are currently tearing down the old one and, if I remember right, are going to use that space as parking lot. I hope that is correct, especially after my visit today. 

I saw three separate vehicles (one on the way in and two on the way out) waiting for somebody to back up and open a spot. No big deal, right? Except that both cars sat and waited for a few minutes. I thought the first car was disabled because it sat there so long. 

The store itself is fine. It's a Super Walmart, so it has the grocery store side. It's a lot like the one in Monona, but without the fun underground parking (best thing I've ever seen in a Walmart) and escalator. I tried to check out using the self-checkout because it is faster when I only have ten items or so. Well, this self-checkout machine was troublesome. It kept telling me I had unauthorized items in bagging area (uh, it was the item I'd just slid over the laser) and then it said I had a restricted item and needed cashier approval to finish up and pay. I didn't have any alcohol, bullets, weapons, or cigarettes. I had a 2-pack of lighters, which was probably it, but why? At any rate, the guy monitoring the self-checkout had to come over and help me three different times. This was in no way faster than just going through a regular register. 

The cashier who helped me to checkout and a guy I asked about Nutella were both nice, but it was an overall frustrating experience. Having the last part be the worst part didn't help.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion because the author experienced frustration and inconvenience during their visit to the new Walmart, specifically with the self-checkout machine and the parking situation, leading to an overall negative experience.

question:
Well it's been 3 years since I last reviewed this Walmart.  Here we are now in 2014 and they've torn down the old, tiny Walmart building and erected a gigantor super Walmart just behind where the old one sat.  I'd like to dance and prance through fields of flowers and sing the praises of this new "super" Walmart, but I can't.  

Have you ever been to a ghost town?  Have you ever been to a ghost store?  *Cue the creepy music*

This super Walmart has all the usual stylings you find at most super Walmarts.  You know what else it has in common with other super Walmarts?  A skeleton crew.  

There are 4 cashiers,manning the 20 check out lanes, and two customer service peeps behind the counter.  All the other employees are stretched as thin as possible to cover the rest of the store.  I'm in sporting goods, I need a fishing license.  Nope.  You will have to walk all the way back to customer service and request help.  They will then call for help in the sporting goods section over the PA.  Next step:  enter the grumpy, overworked employee.  This is the standard MO for all departments.  If you can't help yourself, you will be going on a hunt for the elusive, poorly treated employee.   

This is not unusual for Wally world these days.  Many locations run on a skeleton crew, so the bazillionaire Waltons can save a buck.
rationale: The text shows a negative emotion because it describes the new Walmart as being poorly staffed with a skeleton crew, resulting in customers having difficulty finding assistance and receiving poor service. Predicted emotion: Frustration.

question:
My next-door neighbor, who is 84 and has lived in Sun Prairie all her life, recommended this place for breakfast. It has some very kitschy decor (basic small-town breakfast restaurant style) with lots of gingham and wooden chickens, but I didn't care. 

Nothing on the menu looked very exciting, and it seemed like everything cost a dollar or two more than I would have expected. But the waitress was extremely nice, the coffee was good, and the food (I got the mushroom and cheese omelet) was great. My omelet had three (3!) kinds of cheese and lots of nice 'shrooms inside. It was terrific and also came with hash browns and my choice of toast/pancakes/muffin. I got the rye toast, as always.  

We got there around 8:30am (on a weekday) and almost had the place to ourselves but more people kept trickling in as we ate.
rationale: The text shows positive emotion because the reviewer had a great experience at the breakfast place, enjoying the food and the friendly service, which outweighed any initial doubts about the decor or menu prices. Predicted emotion: Positive.

question: Growing up I always loved their giant cinnamon rolls so while visiting Sun Prairie, I thought I would return to see if they were still as good. The outside of the building is falling apart, which should've been our first clue that they really didn't care about their image. After we got seated, we waited and waited to place our order while the 3 servers on duty stood across from us chatting. Finally, one of the other 3 tables in the restaurant had to interrupt them to ask for more coffee. We sat waiting for a few more minutes for someone to take our order but finally got up and walked out. No one said a word. I'm not even sure they noticed. Skip this dive and go to Sir Hobos. The service at Sir Hobos is always prompt and friendly; their food and menu options are great!
rationale: This review shows negative emotion because the writer had a disappointing experience with slow service and lack of attention from staff at the restaurant, leading them to leave without being acknowledged, contrasting it with a positive experience at another establishment.

question: I hope that a sinkhole opens under this nuisance.  The lack of noise barriers and the racing of unregulated unmuffled cars makes this audible for miles around on Sundays in the summer.  If this was in any other city it would have been closed long ago for noise and pollution inside city limits.  Hopefully the new assistant living community right next door will complain enough that it gets shut down.
rationale: The text expresses negative emotion by criticizing the nuisance caused by the loud, unregulated car racing near residential areas, and hoping for its closure due to noise and pollution issues, suggesting frustration and annoyance.

question: Dear Angell Park, even when I don't know who's behind the wheel any more it's still pretty cool to see those guys drive the hell out of that clay track. Old school fun. Thanks for the nostalgia! You're still cool. Xoxo Stephanie
rationale: This text demonstrates a positive emotion through the use of phrases like "still pretty cool," "old school fun," and "thanks for the nostalgia," all of which convey a sense of enjoyment and admiration towards Angell Park, predicting a sentiment of nostalgia and appreciation.

question:
I'm embarrassed to be writing this review. 
Why, you ask? 
Well it means coping to a number of things: 

1. I was at Dairy Queen. 

I'll stop there. 

Naw, I'll keep going...

2. Even though I'm lactose intolerant, there's just something about a blizzard I can't say no to.  
3. Yes, even Yelp's lover of local winds up at a chain every now and again. It's usually during a dark period or when I'm leaving a meeting in Sun Prairie and I drive by the only DQ I know of in Wisconsin. 
4. The basis for my low rating is a terrible blizzard that crushed all my blizzard dreams. 
5. The real basis for my low rating is the fact that they took out friers, so gone are the days of crisp "chicken" fingers and white bread... seriously why were the baskets served with white bread? 

At the end of the day, the product, and I mean water, maaaaaybe skim milk and flavoring just didn't meet my expectations as blizzards have before. (I told you, I'm embarrassed) Add to this the fact that when it comes to "Brazier" all you can get is a hot dog swimming in funky hot dog water and there's little to no reason for me to stop here anymore. 

I want to take this opportunity to apologize to Michael's, Culver's and most of all Kopps in Milwaukee. I'll never stray again. You shouldn't either.
rationale: The text conveys negative emotion as the reviewer expresses embarrassment and disappointment in their experience at Dairy Queen, detailing their dissatisfaction with the blizzard and the lack of their favorite items on the menu, ultimately apologizing to other, presumably better, fast food establishments for straying. Predicted emotion: disappointment.

question: They may accept pets but also accept smokers--the room smelled like a smoldering pile of  feces laced  vomit.  This place is disgusting--no black light needed to illuminate the extent of filth.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the author describes the place as disgusting and filthy, with a strong unpleasant odor, creating a sense of disgust and disappointment. Predicted emotion: Disgust.

question: Cheapest hotel I could find in the Madison area.  Checking in and out was quick, employees were nice enough, the bed was comfy, the room was clean, and they even had a continental breakfast.  The air conditioning unit was pretty loud so I turned it off at night.  I also recommend bringing your own pillow.  Still, I've stayed at worse, and at $50 a night, the price is unbeatable.
rationale: The review highlights several positive aspects such as quick check-in/out, friendly employees, comfy bed, clean room, and continental breakfast, but also points out minor inconveniences like a loud air conditioning unit and the suggestion to bring your own pillow, ultimately concluding that despite these issues, the hotel is a good value for the price of $50 per night. Thus, the review expresses a positive sentiment overall, as the positive aspects outweigh the negative ones.

question: Stopped in one night for something different. No one seated us or helped us as we arrived. After talking with the bartender, we were seated only to have no waitress. After waving over a waitress the service and the food was sub par. Nasty burgers overcooked. Drinks were ok, that is why they received a 1. Atmosphere was shady and the clientele was inexperienced. Would not return.
rationale: The review shows negative emotion because the customer experienced poor service, subpar food, a shady atmosphere, and felt unwelcome, which would likely lead to disappointment or frustration.

question: There was one waitress for the entire establishment, and unfortunately, this led to extremely poor service. She was overworked, but was unable to be attentive. The salad bar was a total joke - there was hardly any food to choose from in terms of salad or toppings, and the salad that was there looked wilted and gross. Our actual food took over an hour to get to the table, and it was terrible. I ordered a medium steak, which came as well-done as a hockey puck. I cannot believe this restaurant is still open and operating. We will never return.
rationale: The text expresses negative emotion by detailing a series of disappointing experiences at the restaurant, such as poor service, lackluster food options, long wait times, and receiving incorrect orders, leading to a strong sense of frustration and disappointment.

question: Typical WI supper club menu. Good selection of choices. We were there celebrating birthdays on a Sunday afternoon. The Bloody Mary's we're make your own, you got a glass of ice and vodka. The fixings were standard but could have been refilled. Food was good but nothing extraordinary. My only complaint was we ordered a bunch of appetizers for the table and the fried mushrooms were not done and doughy. Probably because of the amount of things we ordered the fryer was not hot enough. \nThe BEST part of the day was the atmosphere. John, the accordion player was celebrating his birthday also. Older crowd but very fun. Waitstaff was friendly and this was more of a large family gathering than a bar. You can never be sad listening to a polka!
rationale: The text mentions positive aspects such as good food, friendly waitstaff, and a fun atmosphere with an older crowd celebrating occasions, which indicate an overall positive experience. This leads to the predicted sentiment of happiness.

question: I recently went to a wedding reception here. I felt sorry for the bride and groom. The place was not clean for starters. The food was the worst part. The salad was soggy from the dressing sitting on it for far too long and then they put on top a hot fresh baked bread stick that came from the freezer, which in turn made the salad hot. I had the sirloin, it was cold, chewy, and bland. My date had the vegetarian pasta, it was over done spinach pasta with some sort of flavorless cream sauce and veggies. Mix in overpriced drinks and you have one of the worst wedding reception venues ever. Stay away!
rationale: The text expresses negative emotion as the reviewer describes a disappointing experience at a wedding reception, highlighting various aspects that were unsatisfactory such as cleanliness, food quality, and overpriced drinks. The overall tone of the review is critical and discouraging, leading to a predicted sentiment of disappointment or dissatisfaction.

question:
My daughter's Quinceañera+/Sweet 16 Formal was held here at Lake Windsor Golf and Country Club on Sunday, April 10th, 2011.  I scouted a few locations, with a few places never getting back to me.  We've a large amount of family and friends for this traditional celebration so I needed a place that was both Big (enough for 300+ guests), Bold (that WOW factor when they even entered the building, foyer and ballroom) and Beautiful (for a place that would accentuate my daughter and her Epic Ballgown.)

I sent an email to Lake Windsor with no response.  Two weeks later I called, turns out my email was never received. See?  It pays to follow-up!  My contact from then on was with Ms. Jennifer Larson, the general manager to Lake Windsor Golf and Country Club.  

I need you to understand that this traditional event was very important.  I have been thinking about my daughters 'Coming of Age' party since she was five (5) and I went into the planning stages of this event early in 2009.  Jennifer and I spoke by phone and we met up the following afternoon. She was very informative, knowledgeable, and welcoming. No one had had such an event there at Windsor so she was very excited about this one!  We read and reviewed the contract, gave her a non-refundable deposit check and we were in the booking book!

My daughter Dylilah and I reviewed the menu and decided on a buffet style lunch and the vendors I worked with (Cake, Balloons Statues, Slide Show, Lion Dancers, etc.) had no issues having access to the property the day of.

If you'd like to see how great it turned out and how beautiful Windsor (and my daughter) really is, we've got the video here: http://youtu.be/DCX7KZQCzcE?t=2m8s

No, they are not inexpensive but, you get what you pay for and truly, I'm sure Lake Windsor will take your wishes and concerns seriously and execute them into an unforgettable time as they did with us!
rationale: The text expresses gratitude and satisfaction towards Lake Windsor Golf and Country Club for hosting a memorable and successful Quinceañera/Sweet 16 Formal event, highlighting the positive experience with the planning process, the venue, and the services provided, ultimately indicating a positive sentiment. Predicted emotion: Positive.

question: Had the best time at a wedding reception here. Highly considering it for my next formal event. The scenery is gorgeous, very spacious, staff is welcoming. It's very clean here and the golf course isn't bad!
rationale: This review shows positive emotion because the reviewer had a great time at the wedding reception, found the scenery gorgeous, the staff welcoming, and the facility clean, with the added benefit of a decent golf course, all factors that contribute to a positive experience. Predicted emotion: Positive sentiment.

question: Good bar and the food is ok not remarkable but good.  Portions sort of skimpy but they ar ealways expanding the menu.  They do have a pretty good Rib eye however but nothing else was that memorable.  I will eat there again I'm sure.
rationale: The text indicates a somewhat neutral or lukewarm sentiment towards the restaurant, with the reviewer mentioning positive aspects like a good bar, a pretty good Rib eye, and the likelihood of returning, but also noting that the food is not remarkable, portions are skimpy, and nothing else was memorable, which might suggest an overall feeling of slight disappointment or ambivalence.

question:
Stuck in Lodi for the day, I couldn't find a place for lunch, and I dared not to try "The Pizza Pit" in town. I thought I'd head east and come here for lunch since I didn't find anything better. Years ago, this used to be a place called Stockade and I loved it. Now it's a Badgers/Packers bar and grill. 

Visible from I-90, just west of Madison, there's a cheese place (Mouse Haus I believe) and warehouses for Pepsi and Walgreen's nearby. The Rodeside Grill resembles a log cabin style fort from the outside. Years ago, this place used to be called Stockade.

Once inside, it's quite spacious with high ceilings and an all wood interior, except for the tile on the floor. The whole place looks very clean, not grungy and aged like so many bars in Wisconsin. I sat down to eat at the bar. All along the bar counter, there were blurbs and excerpts of Packers and Badgers accomplishments underneath the laminated countertop. The place even had green-colored ductwork, so I knew I was deep in Packers territory.

A big screen TV aired game highlights from the Packers-Saints NFL season opener from the day before. Large men with mustaches came in for lunch, typical Wisconsin body types. I kept a low profile and my Chicago origin and calmly requested the Friday fish fry special. Having traveled up north on many occasions, this wasn't the first time I was surrounded by Packer fans. It's not hard to deal with them if you don't disclose where you're from and stick to the menu items or make a positive comment about Jordy Nelson being an awesome rising star on the team.

The fish arrived in a few minutes and it came with a side of fries that were seasoned and coated - quite tasty in fact. Coleslaw is also a can't-miss item north of Illinois and this place has it right too. I found the meal quite enjoyable. The bartender got me another iced tea and then spent a few more minutes of admiring the place. The Packers highlights gave way to NASCAR on the TV, but I was on my way, 150 miles from Chicago once again.

While I went for the fish, Rodeside also has some good burgers, from what I saw around me at lunch that day. Worth a stop on your way to the Dells or Lodi for that matter. Just leave the Bears stuff in the car.
rationale: The text shows positive emotion as the author fondly reminisces about a previously loved restaurant, enjoys the food and atmosphere of the new establishment, and recommends it to others, suggesting a positive sentiment. Predicted emotion: contentment.

question: Everything I have tried here I have loved! I must say that the \"Naughty Crepes\" are by far my favorite breakfast I have ever had. Crepes filled with NUTELLA, strawberries and bananas...to me, that is like HEAVEN! And it tastes every bit as amazing as it sounds. The Apple Chops are some of the best pork chops I have ever had. Large portion size, so I took one home, put it on a bun the next day and had a pork chop sandwich. Amazing flavor, very moist. Also, the Tenderloin Fajita Wrap is very good! Prices seem pretty reasonable to me. Bar drinks are very tasty. Service is so-so. Evening waitresses we've had were all very friendly and gave great service. However, the waitress we had on Sunday morning for breakfast was slow, and was never around when we needed her (although I could see her chatting with the bus boy)!  We overheard her telling other tables, as well as telling us about how difficult her job is and how hungry she was, and how she wished she could eat our meals.  This didn't seem very professional.  Also, she never came back to check and see if we needed anything, and brought us the bill without asking us if we wanted dessert-which we did.  Regardless of the one waitress we had that wasn't up to par, I think this is a great place! I would definitely recommend it!
rationale: The text shows positive emotion overall because the reviewer expresses love for the food, describes it as amazing, and praises the friendly service despite one negative experience with a specific waitress. Predicted Emotion: Positive.

question: Bar is okay and the atmosphere is nice.  Food is below average and pricey. Our food was cold and when we commented on that the sever didn't seem to care.
rationale: The review expresses negative emotion due to the disappointing experience with the below-average, pricey, and cold food, and the lack of satisfactory response from the server when the issue was pointed out.

question: Don't go in the Drive Thru if there are more than 3 cars. You will sit there for 20 minutes.
rationale: This review conveys negative emotion as it describes a frustrating experience of waiting for 20 minutes in the Drive Thru, which can be aggravating and annoying. Predicted sentiment: Frustration.

question: I feel like the food at A&W has continued to go downhill the last few years, and although my visits have become few and far between, the food gets consistently worse. I wish we would have circled around the drive thru and given the food right back. Bland burgers, bland hot dogs, and expensive as all get up. I don't think I'll be back at A&W unless I hear things have gotten better.
rationale: The text expresses negative emotion towards the quality and experience of dining at A&W, highlighting disappointment in the declining food quality, lack of flavor, high prices, and a lack of intention to return unless improvements are made, leading to a predicted emotion of dissatisfaction.

question: My boyfriend and I made a trip to Wisconsin Dells for my birthday and stopped here on the way back to Chicago to get some cheese. All of the employees here were extremely helpful and friendly. Cheese was decent priced and delicious. I'd recommend it.
rationale: The text reflects positive emotion because the writer had a good experience at the cheese store with helpful and friendly employees, reasonably priced and delicious cheese, and ultimately recommends it, showing satisfaction and enjoyment. Predicted sentiment: Positive.

question: Great little shop off of the interstate. I was looking for a place to go that wasn't fast food and wasn't the same old-same old. I was surprised how much I liked this place. Made to order deli-sandwiches, cheese, fudge, a New Glarus beverage and Southern Comfort? Yes, Southern Comfort. True one stop shopping. I will make this a regular stop between Elgin and Minnesota!
rationale: The text expresses positive sentiment by highlighting the pleasant surprise and satisfaction of finding a unique, non-fast food option with a variety of appealing offerings, leading the reviewer to plan on making this a regular stop, indicating a high level of enjoyment and contentment.

question: Stop here! Buy a block of the dill Havarti and try a bunch of samples. I am sure there will be others that you love :)
rationale: This review is positive because it encourages stopping to try a specific item, mentions loving other samples, and uses a smiley face emoticon, indicating a happy and enthusiastic tone. Predicted emotion: Positive

question: Was very disappointed at my recent experience at the mousehouse!!! I have been there before and they had always been so nice not the case this time the lady talked down to us about the difference of white and yellow cheddar and just seemed over all bothered by our presence.  So needless to say we didn't ask for a single sample.  Next time we will not going back.
rationale: The text shows a negative emotion as the writer expresses disappointment at the customer service received at the mousehouse, feeling that they were talked down to and their presence was not valued, leading to the decision not to return in the future. Predicted sentiment: Disappointment.

question:
I'm disappointed by my last stop to the Mousehouse.  I thought I would go outside the box and try the cheese whips (think the string cheese they put in Bloody Mary's), 2 year old sharp cheddar, and the Port Wine Cheese Spread.  Total cost:  $20

The cheddar tasted sweet (I know, weird, right?) and the cheese whips had an off taste and were just nasty, certainly not worth the calories.  The Port Wine Cheese spread was okay but nothing special.  I could have bought something that tasted the same at the grocery.  Disappointed.  

My parents love the Mousehouse and always stop on their way to Milwaukee and always get me the cheese curds.  I will be sticking to those from now on as they are tasty and fresh.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the author expresses disappointment with the cheese products they tried at the Mousehouse, contrasting them unfavorably to the tastier and fresher cheese curds that they usually enjoy, indicating a preference for the latter in the future. Predicted Emotion: Disappointment.

question: We always seem to miss these cheese shops passing through the Dells. We stopped here coming back from Des Plaines in Oct., and it's right off the exit. As you enter there is a display of fudge, but they only want to cut it for you on the way out. Next are all the gadgets and gifts. I got some cool reading glasses, a ghost cheese spreader, body shampoo, a WI shot glass, cheese slicer. We were hosting the upcoming fountain pen meeting and bought a great variety of meats and cheeses. One large beef summer sausage I brought to my thanksgiving hostess. Picked up a cranberry jelly, various crackers. I got to sample all the cheese spreads, and settled on the sharp cheddar. I loved the beef and cheese snack pack because they came in small bites. We left with a few sundries, and of course the fudge. Be prepared to drop at least $100. And this was us restraining ourselves.
rationale: This review shows positive emotion as the writer describes their enjoyable experience at the cheese shop, sampling various products, finding unique items, and being pleased with their purchases. Predicted emotion: Joyful.

question:
Drives into WI are not new to me, family trips during my childhood are some of my fondest memories. But my parents were never ones to make leisurely stops so whenever the chance comes up to stop somewhere cute or kitschy, I HAVE to stop.  And who doesn't love the cute little mouse sitting on a pyramid of cheese?  My husband and I stopped here on the way to MN a few years ago and I am always bugging him to stop here whenever we drive this way.

The MouseHouse offers some great WI items--cheese, beer, wine and cute gifts. I think the prices are reasonable as this most recent time I bought 2 blocks of Buffalo Cheddar, 2 bags of cheese curds, a small tub of bacon cheddar spread and 6 pack bottles of Spotted Cow for only $20plus.

Service is super friendly. They offered us some samples of cheese and offered to place some of my items on the counter for me so I could be hands free to shop some more. The place looks a little rundown, but as long as they keep offering quality products with a smile, we'll keep stopping to shop.


*For the stroller set* Just an FYI, at the time of this review, keep your diaper bag in the car, there is no changing table available in the bathroom.
rationale: The text shows positive emotion as the reviewer fondly reminisces about family trips to Wisconsin, appreciates making leisurely stops, enjoys shopping at MouseHouse for Wisconsin items at reasonable prices, praises the super friendly service, and expresses a desire to stop there again in the future. Predicted sentiment: Positive.

question:
I love cheese! This place is like, I imagine, many others throughout Wisconsin. But since I went to this one and liked it, 5 stars.

We stopped here on a road trip and was happy to see it open before 10. Walking in we saw more than just a cheese house. They had specialty gifts, wine, beer and fudge amongst a haven of cheese. 

The people who worked here were incredibly helpful and friendly. They were happy to give advice about what beer we would like and happily cut samples of cheese. 

Although we only left with a 6 pack of Wisconsin only beer for $9.99, I was tempted to buy much much more. It is possible we will stop on our way back!
rationale: The text shows positive emotion because the reviewer expresses love for the place, appreciation for the helpful and friendly staff, and temptation to buy more products, indicating a pleasant experience overall. Predicted sentiment: Positive.

question:
More than cheese, but cheese...

If you love cheese, you'll like this place.  Heck, even if you don't, there's still plenty of other stuff to look at (beef jerkey, beer/wine, fudge, etc.).  But really, it's abou the cheese.

I love me some fresh cheese curds, and I have yet to be let down here.  If you're weary, just ask someone if they're fresh.  They know, and they'll tell you.  The aged cheddar is pretty great if you're in the mood for that.  I will always grab a bag of mozzarella whips - the kids and I will take care of those before they hit the fridge.

My dad is a big fan of this place as well.  He'll get an order of brick or some other stinky cheese before heading south and they'll give it a couple extra dips in wax to help it travel better.
rationale: The text shows positive emotion because it discusses the variety and quality of cheeses available at the store, the satisfaction of consistently enjoying fresh cheese curds, and the special treatment given to customer orders to ensure the cheese travels well. The overall tone is enthusiastic and appreciative, leading to a predicted emotion of satisfaction.

question: If you're on a road trip and looking to get famous cheese from Wisconsin, Mousehouse Cheesehaus is the place for you. We spotted the big mouse and sign from the highway and promptly pulled off.\nThey had the Friendliest staff, with workers eager to give samples of fudge and cheese. You could've sampled all day for all they minded. We bought fudge- the deal was buy one pound, get half a pound for free. How could we pass that up? That's SIX types of fudge. Delicious. The shop is great as well. Tried on the cheese hats (a must) and bought a cheese wedge beer holder. Have fun.
rationale: The text shows positive emotion because the author describes the friendly staff, the abundance of samples, the great deal on fudge, the deliciousness of the products, and the fun atmosphere of the shop, all of which contribute to an overall positive experience. Predicted sentiment: Positive.

question:
Easy stop off the highway for cheese of all kinds, jerky, beer, gifts and souvenirs. Cheese Curds are a must, and are available in a variety of flavors. We chose Cajun, but there are also the classics: plain yellow or white, or a mix of the two. We also purchased a "beer cheese." The staff is super friendly and more than willing to let you try any samples you'd like. There were some great cheese spreads we tried, too. I especially liked the Port Wine...reminded me of grandma's house, and the Horseradish.

We each had a sandwich and enjoyed them! I opted for hard salami with the house Mousehouse Jack. It was nice and toasty, melty, and delicious. D got a Reuben. The House Sauce was particularly stand-out. 

Oh, and of course the fudge was too tempting to pass up. Thank goodness we don't live in Wisconsin. We'd be as big as houses...and not Mousehouses either.
rationale: The text describes a positive experience at a cheese shop, highlighting the variety of products available, the friendly staff, delicious sandwiches, and tempting fudge, all contributing to a sense of enjoyment and satisfaction, indicating a positive emotion of satisfaction and contentment.

question: I was a member of Summit Credit Union for over 10 years, and I've always been a huge fan of credit unions... My mom had even worked for their corporate office for awhile. I had taken out a loan through them during college to help consolidate the debt I incurred from school, and a few years ago (about half way through my loan) I was laid off when the economy collapsed. I was struggling with my bills and though I had taken out the insurance for job loss, they found a loop hole and didn't credit me with the insurance, even though I had been paying the extra $50 for the insurance for over 2 years. Then I contacted them multiple times trying to reasses my monthly payment, as I couldn't keep up with all of my bills, I spoke with Mary in the finance department and through our conversation she was rude and extremely hostile. She accused me of lying when I told her I had been calling in and trying to find a solution, when I asked her if I still paid my payments but paid less, she said that they would send me to collections for not making the full amount. Then she looked in my account and saw that I had money in there (enough for only 2 months of rent and my bills... will no real income coming in) and said that there was obviously no reason I was having problems and I shouldn't have even called her. I was really frustrated, I was trying to negotiate so I didn't have to file bankruptcy. Then after I could no longer pay, due to my dire financial situation, they took out all the money I had in my account and applied it towards the loan... i.e. my rent, without any phone calls or letters reaching out to me before they were going to take my money. Ultimately, I had to file for bankruptcy, but I would never ever bank with them again.
rationale: The text highlights a series of negative experiences with Summit Credit Union, including being denied insurance coverage despite paying for it, encountering hostility and rudeness from staff, threats of sending the borrower to collections, and unilaterally taking money from the borrower's account without notice, resulting in the borrower having to file for bankruptcy. Predicted sentiment: negative emotion. Rationale: The borrower's frustration and disappointment are evident throughout the text due to the unfair treatment, lack of empathy, and financial difficulties caused by the credit union's actions.

question: Brought some cds in to sell.  Got a little more than I expected, and they took a couple things I wasn't sure anyone but me liked (Vanessa Mae, some jazz; but I guess most of my friends are indie rock people).  Lots of stuff, great selection of vinyl.  I liked the tape collection, and might be back to get some tapes for my '99 subaru.  :)  Also sells DVDs/movies etc.
rationale: The review expresses a positive emotion by highlighting that the individual got more money than expected for their CDs, found a great selection of vinyl, enjoyed the tape collection, and is considering purchasing tapes for their car, which indicates satisfaction and excitement for the items available at the store. Predicted emotion: Positive sentiment.

question: I was not very impressed at all when I recently went in to check out the used record selection. Many of the pop/rock titles seemed overpriced for their condition. This store does not seem very picky about what is selected to sell, like they'll just put anything into their bins and slap a price on it, no matter how shabby it appears (I felt like mold spores were being released into the air as I looked through the albums). Jazz section seemed a bit better in item quality, but was a pretty small selection. If you are ga-ga over used cassettes, they have plenty of 'em (kind of an insane amount). CD selection is average. Younger girl working behind the counter seemed apathetic to be there. All in all, I'd pass on this store. (They also display some more rare vinyl outside of the store, but the covers are all very faded due to sunlight exposure...a bizarre choice for displaying such items!)
rationale: This text shows negative emotion because the reviewer was unimpressed with the store's used record selection, found the pricing unreasonable, criticized the quality and selection of items, and noted a lack of enthusiasm from the staff, ultimately leading them to advise against visiting the store.

question: Might be the worst vinyl focused store I've been into. I'd say 80% of the records, including the whatever Beatles records in the \"collectibles\" box are beat to heck (and five times the price they should be for the condition). They didn't put records in plastic sleeves. Beat 80s pop records that should be $1-2 in NM/NM shape are $6.50, but hey, there is a buy one get one half price, or something like that special. Really, the dregs of records. I flipped a little bit but there was absolutely nothing. Most of these records should be dumpstered. I'm super pro indie record stores, but sometimes when three other stores pass on stuff there is a reason it shouldn't be put out.
rationale: The review shows negative emotion as the author expresses disappointment with the quality and pricing of the records, using phrases like "worst vinyl focused store," "beat to heck," and "the dregs of records." Predicted sentiment: Disappointment.

question: I really like Java Detours drinks. Especially the Oreo Latte, yum!Employees are always very friendly. The one thing that disappointed me is that they had a punch card for customers (buy 10 drinks get one free) and I devotedly brought it with me everytime I went there to get it punched. I was one punch away from a free drink when I handed my punch card over to the employee and she said sorry they discontinued them. I was very disappointed. I understand if they discontinued the punch card concept, but at least honor the ones that are still in circulation!
rationale: This text shows a negative emotion because the customer had a negative experience with the discontinuation of the punch card despite being one punch away from a free drink, which left them feeling disappointed and frustrated.

question: i really, really like this place - not just because it's right by my house and it's NOT starbucks, but those things certainly don't hurt.\n\ni love that they have a drive-thru. i love that the staff are genuinely nice people. i love their tiny little nicely-decorated seating area. and, most importantly, i love their tasty, reasonably priced coffee.
rationale: This review expresses positive emotion by highlighting various aspects the reviewer loves about the place, such as the convenient location, friendly staff, cozy seating area, and good coffee, all contributing to a positive experience overall.

question: There service here is AWESOME.  I love coming here mainly for the service.  I don't have a favorite drink, but \"Mocha\" is a place where you can be comfortable enough to ask what a particular drink is and you won't get a snippy answer.  So I always try something different and I've liked every one of the drinks I've had.  I'm excited to try their iced drinks now that the weather is warming up.  \n\nI also like that you can now get a little treat like muffins or different breads.  When I'm in the mood for a coffee and sweet treat, they always pop into mind.
rationale: The review demonstrates positive emotion as the reviewer expresses their love for the awesome service, appreciation for the variety of drinks and treats offered, excitement to try new items, and satisfaction with the overall experience, indicating a favorable sentiment of satisfaction or happiness.

question: I know... it's Target, but it's got pretty much everything you need short of a butcher shop and babysitters. Staff is very helpful... it also houses the closest Starbucks to my home. Since we're talking about 2 miles, that's a bit sad, but oh well..
rationale: The text expressing disappointment that the nearest Starbucks is 2 miles away from the reviewer's home, despite being located in a convenient store, contributes to a negative sentiment. Predicted emotion: Disappointment.

question: This Target is a good one. Usually pretty well-stocked for things you need and the more recent mid-sized grocery section usually has a decent amount of stuff when you're in need of this or that and already at Target. \n\nOne downside is that they usually could use a few more cashiers up front when things are busy. I've often had to wait a bit longer than seems reasonable to pay for a purchase.
rationale: The review mentions how the Target store is usually well-stocked and convenient for shoppers, but highlights the downside of long wait times at the checkout counter, which can be frustrating, indicating a negative sentiment due to the inconvenience experienced by the reviewer.

question: The Mrs. went to get a blender there today. The unit she wanted was not available in a box ready for purchase, only had one on the display shelf. She asked for help. The reply from boy-flunky: \"oh, they are in the back and hard to find'. Gee, could you be any more motivated? He relented and returned with negative results. Bet he looked real hard. Come on. Any you wonder why American brick and mortar commerce is failing. We are shopping on Amazon tonight.
rationale: The text demonstrates a negative emotion because it describes a frustrating experience with a unhelpful employee at a store, highlighting the lack of customer service and motivation, which can lead to dissatisfaction and a preference for online shopping platforms like Amazon.

question:
I have been a regular at Myle's nails for years.  The service has been spotty as is in many discount nail salons but I've returned because the prices are very competitive and nothing terrible has ever happened...until now.

The last time I went in for a full set of gels the technician was extremely rough and couldn't understand what I was saying when I told him he was hurting me.  He ground down my pinky nail trying to remove an ink stain that I said was fine and to please leave it be.  It left a painfully sensitive divot in my nail.  Also, he was so rough with the sanding drill and nail file that when I left, every one of cuticles was bleeding.  My fingers were throbbing for two days until they scabbed over.

I decided to call and talk to the manager who told me I was "too nice" and that I should have "stood up and said something" about the poor nail job.  He told me that in the future I should call ahead and request someone different (even though they accept walk ins).  He tried to make me feel like it was my fault. 

I have worked in customer service for almost 5 years and I am not one to complain in order to receive free services or goods. However, the manager should have at least offered me a free manicure to make up for such a bad experience.

I won't be back :(
rationale: This text demonstrates negative emotion as the individual had a painful and unsatisfactory experience with their nail service, including rough treatment, bleeding cuticles, and dismissive behavior from the manager, ultimately leading them to decide not to return in the future. Predicted emotion: Disappointment.

question: I got a pedicure for $30 and it was exceptional! Great for the price. It included a hot stone massage, calf massage, and the nail technician did excellent work. I love Myles Nails and the other review was not deserved.
rationale: The text expresses positive emotion because the individual had an exceptional experience getting a pedicure at Myles Nails, highlighting the great value for the price, high-quality service, and satisfaction with the overall experience.

question: Love everything about this place! My family has been ordering carry out from here for at least 10 years. It's the best Chinese on this side of town. The lo mein rocks!
rationale: The text expresses positive emotion by highlighting a long-standing connection with the restaurant, praising the quality of the Chinese food, and specifically mentioning the delicious lo mein, indicating satisfaction and enjoyment. Predicted sentiment: Positive.

question: Way too sweet for my liking. Real authentic Chinese food isn't always sweet. In my opinion, if you like sweet taste this much, might as well eat candy bar dip in corn syrup as a meal. When I ordered my food a few years back from them, they put too much food coloring so much that it looked yellow. It was not appealing to me. But it has been years I haven't been there so they could have improved and better. I sure hope that's the case.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the reviewer expresses displeasure with the overly sweet and artificially colored food, indicating a lack of authenticity and appeal, but ends on a slightly hopeful note suggesting that the restaurant may have improved over the years, leading to a mixed sentiment.

question:
One liner for quick reads:  Fresh made Hot and Sour soup!

Yes...they make the Hot and Sour Soup when you order it...no gelatinous, nasty leftovers here.  

Service can be a little slow, but definitely worth it.  Good overall food. Our favorite Chinese takeout.  (note...we always pick up, so I cannot comment on the delivery)
rationale: The review describes the Hot and Sour soup as freshly made with no leftover gelatinous texture, portraying a positive and appetizing image which is likely to elicit a positive sentiment.

question: My daughter and I stopped in last night for the first time.  I had the Chicken Chop Suey and she had Sweet & Sour Chicken.  We started with an order of Steamed Dumplings.  The dumplings were great.  They had a lot of meat in them.  The Chop Suey was made with a white sauce.  I am used to it being made with a brown sauce.  That did not matter as it was delicious.  The S&S Chicken was wonderful as well.  The S&S sauce that came with it was not laden with all that bright red food coloring.  Very tasty.   She also got an Egg Roll.  It was huge!  We had to split it.  Niiice.  And, even though you order and pick your food up at a counter, the service was great.  I ordered a Chicken Lo Main to go for my son and she asked me if I wanted them to wait a bit before they cooked it.  I like that!  That tells me that they care about our experience after I pay them!!  A plus!  We've passed this place up numerous times.  Not any more.  We'll be back!
rationale: This text demonstrates positive emotion as the reviewer describes enjoying the food, appreciating the service, and expressing a desire to return in the future, leading to a predicted emotion of satisfaction.

question:
Easily the worst Chinese food that I've eaten. And I've eaten my fair share, trust me.

Our General Tso's Chicken was terrible. Very bland and overcooked. The flavor was also very strange, and tasted like ketchup. Just terrible.

The crab rangoon weren't much better. As I watched an employee take the frozen rangoon from the freezer and dump them into the deep fryer, I didn't have very high expectations, but wow. Mushy and weird-tasting.

The interior of this joint is also disgusting. Wallpaper is peeling off the walls, and in general it looked filthy.

Customer service was also really bad. When I finally got my food and said said my goodbye, the woman at the counter didn't even acknowledge me and went back to watching TV behind the counter. I completely understand the language barrier, but the 2 employees working weren't even trying.

The price I paid for the food was also way too high, considering the very low quality of my meal.

We stopped in around 6 pm and it was completely dead. I am really puzzled why this place is still open.

Avoid.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion by detailing multiple disappointing aspects of the Chinese restaurant experience, such as poor food quality, hygiene issues, bad customer service, high prices, and lack of customers, leading to an overall feeling of frustration and disappointment.

question: Old Navy is one of those places that I totally forgot existed until my sister became employed there. Now, I shop here at least twice a month. They are forever having some kind of clearance or sale going on and they a lot of sizes. I believe they go from an XS to a XXL, however, if they do not have your size in stock, they will call over to the West side Old Navy or order it for you online. I have found it that online does have more plus size apparel. They sale shoes, accessories, skirts, dresses, shorts, hats, bags, graphic t-shirts and so on. Great store to go to if you're looking for a nice spring dress for a great price. You can also apply for a credit card and get approved immediately.
rationale: The text shows positive emotion because the reviewer highlights the variety of sizes available, frequent clearance sales, and the option to order online if your size is unavailable, praising the store as a great option for finding affordable spring dresses. Predicted emotion: positive.

question: Sale! 1.00 fleece hats and 2.00 fleece scarves. Mix and match. Icy cold wind whips right off the lakes near capital.
rationale: The text mentions a sale with low prices and encourages mixing and matching, while also emphasizing the icy cold wind near the lakes, which can evoke a sense of urgency or discomfort, indicating a negative sentiment such as frustration or annoyance.

question: Corp store on Lien rd was not a good choice.  The manager of the store was very unhelpful and gave me the run around about trying to fix my phone. If you want good service with people who actually care, go to the store on University Ave
rationale: The text expresses negative emotion by highlighting poor customer service and lack of helpfulness from the store manager, leading the reviewer to recommend another store for better service, suggesting dissatisfaction and frustration.

question: I went into get a replacement phone and received one....1.5 months later.  The first time I went to have my phone looked at I waited for more than an hour in line as employees milled about seemingly aimlessly.  When I was finally called up, they took my phone and told me to wait for another hour.  I walked around the mall for an hour and came back to find that they couldn't fix it...Fine 2 hours of my life burned but fine.  I was urged to upgrade in 10 days and I went home to think about it.  A week or two later I returned again and was told that they would put in an order for my replacement phone and that it would be shipped to me...14 days later I returned to ask where my phone was...The sales rep confirmed that the order was still just sitting on the technician's desk in the back room.  Wonderful.  At this point I call corporate and make a ruckus and the manager of the store calls me to assure me that the phone has been ordered, \"I will call you when it comes in.\"  12 days later I call to ask where the phone is and they tell me it has been in for 10 days and assure me that they called me about it.  No.  Finally my replacement phone is received but after 30 mins fiddling with it, they tell me they can't transfer my contacts...Not from my old phone to a new variety of phone...from the same make and model to the same make and model.  I am beyond disgust.
rationale: This text shows negative emotion as the individual describes a series of frustrating experiences with getting a replacement phone, highlighting multiple delays, lack of communication, and incompetence from the store employees. Predicted sentiment: frustration.

question: Well i went into this store to check out the iphone deal its a scam to get you in the store what they dont tell you is that it really is not fifty bucks as advertised. After some crazy fees that no one can explain to u in an honest english language and taxes the package comes out to about 90.00 a month hmmmm how did the fifty as advertised become 90.00 - american scammery and fast talking salesman who know that the american public has been conditioned to accept this bull shit - ppl read !!!!! Ask questions!!!!!!! Call them on their crap!!!!!!!!!

question: I have come here twice, the first time I came here I got a blended coffee drink that wasn't terrible but wasn't memorable either... then the next time I came I got a sandwich that was pretty good but I could of made the same thing at home.... the staff is friendly though.. but I won't be going back....

question: Awful. The sweat panted ( hey put a little effort in to it ) crabby ( if you you think your job sucks find a different one ) ' barista' ( being able to work an espresso machine is not that much more difficult than a mr coffee) at least gave me some fodder for crappy service reviews. question: The staff sucks beyond rude. Shouldn't be in business. Don't know how to make drinks. Don't waste your time or money going to this place. The nut job lady in the morning needs to be on meds.
