The place has gotten quite a dramatic face-lift. It looks great. I love everything they've done with the place.

I tried the Tip Top Burger and the chili. The burger was fine, but not spectacular. The chili was really freaking delicious, though. I would highly recommend grabbing a bowl. 

The space is pretty small, but there is actually a lot of seating. It does get pretty loud though. The staff members were all very nice and did a great job. The bitchy people  next to us were treated a lot nicer than they deserved. A waiter mixed up an order and was very apologetic and quickly resolved the issue.

Overall, I'm happy that the place is finally open. A welcome addition to the neighborhood.
rationale: The text demonstrates positive emotions by praising the renovations, delicious food (especially the chili), ample seating, friendly staff, and efficient service, ultimately expressing happiness and satisfaction with the new establishment opening in the neighborhood.

question:
I stopped by the Tip Top yesterday evening with some coworkers to finally check it out. I've been curious since renovations began and was expecting great things. After a late shift, we were there for drinks and light food. The place was bustling, and yes noisy, yet we could still have a conversation without straining at a table near the back wall - so don't be afraid to bring a friend here if you actually want to chat. Selection was great and everything that we ordered (and actually received) was excellent. The fried pickles are crispy, delicious, and done right.

However after waiting a half hour for an order of chicken wings, we were able to grab our server's attention and ask about my wings. "Oops," she said. And then a not very satisfying apology. Having already waited a half hour, we were wrapping our night up and I said, "Let's forget them" since she was offering any solutions. 

Somewhere between ordering the wings and realizing we wouldn't get them, our server told us she was taking off for the night and asked us to settle up with her. Our bill was completely off. You could say the free beers offset the lost order but it definitely wasn't intentional since the bill came first.

I have high expectations of customer service and Tip Top Tavern failed, which is too bad because I was really beginning to like the place.
rationale: The text shows a negative emotion as the reviewer expected great things from the Tip Top Tavern due to renovations, but experienced long wait times for food, a lackluster apology for mistakes, and incorrect billing, leading to disappointment in the customer service which contrasted with the initial positive impression. Predicted emotion: Disappointment.

question:
I could say "This is a tip top spot!" but that would be CHEESY and my New Year's resolution 23 years ago was to avoid such things.

ANYways. I definitely liked the ambiance of this space a lot. A charming neighborhood bar with horizontal narrow wood paneling, lower lighting, tiled floor, tin ceiling, and a very pretty border/trim around the ceiling. Being a small-ish space with lower ceilings and hard floors, it does get a bit noisy when the place fills up so best to beat the rush if you're sensitive to that sort of thing. Also, it's another CASH ONLY spot so be sure to stock up or else they have an ATM on site.

My co-workers and I headed here for drinks one Friday. The place seemed to have a "must order food" policy in order to be seated at the tables so 15 of us frustratingly spent a bit of time crowded at the entrance, downing beers, trying to decide if we should move on. Fortunately, I think the staff finally figured out that two beers basically equals the cost of a sandwich (so what's the difference) and we got a nice row of tables.  Whew!  The place was definitely running a wait by 6:30pm so, again, head out early/late!

The Mister and I headed here at 6pm on a Saturday and were able to snag the last open table in the place. The beer list is good and reasonably priced ($4).  The menu offers burgers, apps, and sandwiches and sports several vegetarian options. Mr. had the special (Walleye sandwich) which he enjoyed while I had the Seitan Philly ($8.95), also tasty. We started with the cheese curds ($5.95) which were yummy. I'd previously had the kettle chips/dip, which were just that, chips/dip, nothing fancy and the fried pickles which weren't my favorite... 

All in all I really liked the ambiance (but I'd go early so I can hear better) and appreciate the reasonably priced & yummy options for both vegetarians and carnivores.  I hope they are able to work out the kinks along the way (i.e., must order food to get a seat policy) but overall think this is a very nice addition to the neighborhood.
rationale: The review indicates positive emotion as it praises the ambiance, reasonably priced menu with vegetarian options, and overall positive experience despite some minor inconveniences, thus predicting a sentiment of satisfaction or contentment.

question:
Small but high-quality menu selections with locally sourced foods. Good value for what you get.  Great selection of microbrew beers. Our waiter was very attentive and a nice guy.
 
TheTip Top Tavern has opened again after a major remodel. It was well worth the wait. It is now cozy, cute, and tiny. 

Great for those who prefer unique destinations over corporate chains.
rationale: The review highlights positive aspects such as high-quality menu selections, locally sourced foods, good value, a great selection of microbrew beers, attentive service, and a cozy, cute, and unique ambiance after a major remodel. This showcases a positive sentiment as the reviewer is pleased with the overall experience and offerings at the Tip Top Tavern.

question:
Stopped by for a late meal on a Thursday night and the place was quite lively, but there were still a few tables open.  The servers all seemed to be having a good time and took excellent care of us, checking in just enough but not too much.  

The menu is small, but has something for everyone.  We tried the carnitas - flavorful and tender - and a burger - expertly seasoned and juicy.  Both were slightly overcooked: the burger arrived more medium rare than the requested rare, and on the carnitas the yolk of one fried egg was deliciously soft, while the other was just a bit too set.  However the high quality ingredients and delightful flavors evened out any imperfections.  The drink menu was well rounded and we enjoyed both the beer and cocktails.  

The small touches in design elevate the interior from the ordinary in an entirely pleasing way.  Tip Top is a great addition to the neighborhood and I look forward to enjoying it again soon.
rationale: The review illustrates positive emotion by highlighting the enjoyable atmosphere, attentive service, delicious food with high-quality ingredients and delightful flavors, well-rounded drink menu, and the pleasing design touches that elevate the overall experience, ultimately expressing excitement about returning in the future.

question:
Love!   We will be back, and back often.  As our summer Saturday dining trek continues this is the epitome of what we want.  A local joint, that just makes you comfortable and glad to be out.

Arrived about 6:30 on a Saturday, and found our way to the new back patio.  A couple of larger groups, but plenty of choice of seating.  Found our table, and service was immediate-friendly, attentive, and just exceptional.  KR had barely ordered and couldn't stop gushing about her love of this place.  
We started with the fried pickles, based on previous reviews, and they were perfectly done.
KR had the Rooster sandwich and enjoyed it so much, she only offered me a tiny bite, As I'm unable to order the same, I was forced to the Tip Top burger, and was not disappointed.  Perfectly done, and flavor throughout.
After another beverage, and just enjoying the evening, we got our check and headed out.
Thanks to other reviews, we knew CASH only, but there is an ATm, so heads up!

Perfect, exactly what we wanted, and this sets the bar for us for the balance of our summer Saturday dining trek.
rationale: The text is filled with positive descriptors such as "love," "perfectly done," "enjoyed," "exceptional service," and "glad to be out," as well as expressing excitement about returning multiple times, which shows a high level of satisfaction and contentment, predicting a positive emotion.

question:
Finally go to the Tip Top last night for dinner and had a great experience.  Great job with the remodel, and the outdoor patio is very nice as they put up a high enough fence to block the street and make it private, but it is lareg enough to be fun.
  Excellent liquor and beer selections at reasonable prices.  Food was way better than expected - huge portions, excellent quality, and nicely different than the usual Madtown fare.  

We had fried pickles which were done with tempura batter so they were not heavy and the slight sweetness of the batter nicely offset the brininess of the pickles.  Huge basket with a great home made dipping sauce ( a remoulade) as well.   Then, thank God cause it is also big, we split a plate of two pepper mac 'n cheese, which was cooked perfectly and the jalapenos were offset perfectly by the poblanos for a flavorful balance.  

Twelve taps, good cocktails, great service and a friendly atmosphere.  Hope you do well Tip Top!
rationale: This review expresses positive emotion by highlighting various aspects of the dining experience that exceeded the customer's expectations, such as the great remodel, excellent food and drink selections, large portions, and friendly atmosphere, leading to a hopeful wish for the restaurant's success.

question:
Food:  The fried pickles with special sauce are very good.  The breading is like the batter from a good fish fry, and the pickles are cut in deliciously thin chips.  The sweet potato fries were also quite good, but they were cold when they got to us.  I always appreciate it when a restaurant goes the extra mile to make their own vegetarian burger.  This one was fair and had a southwest flavor to it.  The macaroni and cheese (which does not come with the cilantro or parsley mentioned on the menu) was pretty bad.  You could eat the top layer off, but the bottom layer was completely flooded with oil.

Service:  The server was very friendly and courteous.  However, we only got a refill on the water when the check came.  Like most pubs, be prepared for a pretty good wait before you get your food.  And, there appeared to be some issue with misplacing our appetizer order.  

Atmosphere:  Fun and kind of hipster.   There is a nice outdoor patio, but be aware that it is dog friendly.  This means that you may have someones poorly trained dog licking your feet during dinner.  This also means that all of the servers and staff will pet the dogs while handling your food.  If this is a concern for you, consider a different restaurant.

Price: Very reasonable.  Starters were about $5 and entrees were less than $10.

Payment:  Cash only

Parking: Street, but there seemed to be plenty of spaces.

I love Tip Top Tavern's sister restaurant - Lazy Janes - and I would like to come back for brunch.  And, the new ownership has done some great things to the restaurant.  But, I would not come back for dinner.  The food was fair to poor, and the dog issue is unappetizing.
rationale: The review displays negative emotion as it highlights issues with the quality of the food, slow service, the presence of dogs in the dining area, and the unappetizing nature of dogs being around the food. Predicted emotion: Disappointment.

question: Poor service by the wait staff is my biggest complaint. We were there at 5:00 (and it wasn't busy yet), and it took probably 15 minutes to place our order. \n\nFinally, $16.95 for a fish fry. Yowzers!
rationale: The text expresses negative emotion as the reviewer is dissatisfied with the slow service and high price of the fish fry, using phrases like "biggest complaint" and "Yowzers!"

question:
I have been on two trips to Top Top now, and figured it was time to write a quick review. I've done weeknight dinner and Sunday brunch.

The weeknight we stopped in was a beautiful night for patio eating. My partner and I both had the Tip Top burgers and they were wonderful. Nice albeit modest selection of beers on tap (disclaimer: we moved from Milwaukee where anything less than a novel in a beer menu is modest) and just an all around pleasant experience. Service was good--relaxed but not too distant--and we were in and out in decent time.

Brunch was a few days ago and nearer to memory. I stopped in with a friend who ordered the pastrami hash and I had the veggie benedict. Mint and avocado? Apparently delicious! My only minor complaint on the benedict was that the tomatoes weren't quite ripe, but as my own garden will attest it's been a rough tomato year. My friend who has a gluten allergy was delighted to learn that they offer gluten free bread and said his hash was delicious. It was pretty quiet, just us and a few other people around noon. Hoping other people find this little neighborhood gem soon. Just, you know, not when I want to be there, it's nice to have some room to stretch out ;).
rationale: The text shows positive emotion as the reviewer highlights the wonderful food, pleasant experience, good service, and the availability of gluten-free options at Top Top, expressing delight and hoping for the restaurant's continued success, which predicts a positive emotion.

question: I love this friendly, neighborhood gym. It has everything you could want - cardio, weights, machines, trainers, power-lifting/strong man equipment, boxing, plus yoga and martial arts classes upstairs. This old-school gym is all about working out!  :-)
rationale: The text expresses a positive emotion by highlighting the variety of equipment and classes available at the gym, praising its old-school focus on working out, and using a positive emoticon at the end. Predicted emotion: joyful.

question: Madison's Hardest Working Gym. With the closing of the Cemetery circa 1992, Ford's - formally Muscles & Fitness remains Madison's only real gym. It's where you go to get in shape when the mega clubs have failed you. It's where you go to get strong, to be strong. It also has arguably one of the countries best Boxing programs, which has been nurtured by the legendary Bob Lynch. If you don't know who Bob Lynch is, look it up. \n\nFord's has something for everyone - Strong Man equipment, Olympic gear, classic Powerlifing equipment and more. The place is always a bit dusty and musty... Why... Because it's a Freaking Gym, not a club or a spa. This is a place where legends train and are made.
rationale: The text exudes positive emotion by highlighting the gym as a place where people go to get strong, featuring a renowned boxing program and a variety of equipment to cater to different fitness needs, while emphasizing the gritty atmosphere that reflects its focus on serious training and creating legends. Predicted sentiment: Positive.

question: I started going here on and off about eight years ago. The pizza is the best, but the burgers (veggie and regular) are very good as well. It's bar food at its very best. Hot chips with dipping sauce are good too! There's often bands on the weekends, and the occasional lesbian after bowling league get together, but not angry, man-hating, shemales. Quite a few different groups of people get together for good beer, food and music at reasonable prices.
rationale: The review mentions positive aspects such as the quality of the pizza and burgers, the good atmosphere with bands playing on weekends, and the diverse group of people gathering for good food and drinks, which overall creates a sense of enjoyment and satisfaction.

question: Some of the best bar food in the state.  Burgers and Pizza are always a fantastic choice.  Entertainment is hit or miss, but at least they have some.  However, my favorite reason to go here is it serves the coldest tap beer ever!!!
rationale: The text indicates overall positive sentiment by highlighting the positive aspects of the venue such as the great food options, availability of entertainment, and particularly the exceptional service of serving the coldest tap beer, which would likely evoke feelings of enjoyment and satisfaction from the reader.

question:
I just want to mention that we came back on a Sunday afternoon at around 8:30.  We ordered burgers and cheese curds.  They tasted a lot like burgers and cheese curds.  I also don't think the prices are that great on further reflection.  6 dollars for a stinkin cheeseburger?  That's not great...  3 dollars for a pabst?  

But the place was kid free this time.  That's nice.  

I would give higher ratings, but some drunk regular yelled at us for ordering from the menu instead of the "board."  Unpleasant.
rationale: The review expresses negative emotion as the author discusses disappointment in the taste and prices of the food, along with annoyance at a drunk regular's behavior, overall leading to an unpleasant experience. Predicted sentiment: negative.

question:
Oh how I miss you, Harmony Bar!  I never miss a chance to grab a walnut burger and hot chips when I'm back in town.  

This is just a wonderful neighborhood bar.  The food is still "bar" food but it's quality, tasty and made fresh to order.  The pizza is good, too.  Good beer selection and a truly local atmosphere.  The Harmony fits right into the vibe of the neighborhood.

Oh how I miss you, Harmony Bar!
rationale: The text expresses a strong sense of nostalgia and longing for the Harmony Bar, highlighting the positive memories associated with the place, which indicates a positive emotion of sentimentality and fondness.

question: I like bars that are a little rough around the edges, but they don't usually have good food.  Harmony, on the other hand, manages to come through quite nicely in the food department.\n\nI had a walnut burger and an order of their potato chips which they apparently make fresh.  The burger was great.  Large but not too large, a little bit messy, and just the right amount of toppings.  The chips were great too... at first.  Though I have to say that they started to feel a bit heavy about half way through.  They're still good, just be warned that if you eat an entire thing of chips your heart might explode.
rationale: The review highlighted positive aspects such as the great burger and freshly made potato chips at Harmony, but also mentioned a slight downside with the chips feeling heavy halfway through, overall showing a positive sentiment with some minor critique. Predicted sentiment: positive.

question:
If I could give the Harmony less than one star, I would. I live in the Shenk-Atwood neighborhood, so I'm not writing as an outsider. I've been to the Harmony many times, but I'm finally done being abused by the notoriously unfriendly owner, bartenders and waitstaff at the Harmony. The Harmony is worse than Seinfeld's Soup Nazi because there's no irony or humor in being treated the way the employees here treat their customers. 

I won't get into specifics. I can only say that I take pride in my neighborhood. My wife and I frequent those establishments that understand that they are part of a community and treat their paying customers as such. The Harmony is a black mark on our neighborhood, and I am ashamed that unsuspecting visitors to the quaint east side should have to endure the abusive, disrespectful and generally unapologetic service at this establishment. If you scroll down you'll read other comments about the owner's girlfriend who is now manager. The last time I was in there with a group of friends, she couldn't have been more rude or insulting. When we all said we wouldn't be back, she merely shrugged her shoulders. 

If you're visiting the East Side, there are plenty of other places that serve great food with friendly service. Alchemy, Mickey's, Wilson's, The Weary Traveller all come to mind as places that will make you feel and taste the love on the East Side.  If you're a masochist, be sure to head on over The Harmony for your daily dose of abuse. 

You've been warned. You certainly won't catch me sitting at this bar ever again.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the reviewer expresses dissatisfaction and disappointment with the service at The Harmony, highlighting instances of abuse, disrespect, and rudeness. Predicted sentiment: Anger/frustration.

question:
The unfriendly atmosphere at The Harmony Bar is its biggest failing.  At first I thought it was just sarcastic "Soup Nazi" humor, but soon realized that the prevalent hostile attitude there is genuine and that it trickles down from management to employees, customers, and even performers.  I've seen bar managers there either berate customers directly or berate the bartenders who then have to try very hard not to pass that negativity on to customers.

Also, it's downright embarrassing to be an audience member there when the bar mistreats the band.  I once saw a Harmony bar manager preempt an encore performance by turning on the overhead lights, jumping up on the stage, and literally grabbing the mike from a performer to announce that the show's over and that everybody has to finish their drinks and leave.  I was floored.  It was the first time I'd ever seen anyone kick a band off the stage just because they wanted to close their bar early.  

The kitchen staff works hard, and the food is decent.  Unfortunately, this is the only bar I've ever been to in Madison where I've been asked to pay for my dinner tab up front.  (There are lots of other bars that also don't take credit cards, but they still let you run a tab.) It made me wonder if they didn't trust me to close out my tab or if they were hoping my tip would be better prior to experiencing their poor service.

In short, even on occasions when they book national acts, it's not worth going there if you're going to encounter hostility when you want something from the bar.  There are too many other fun places to go in Madison for anyone to have to put up with the miserable buzz killing atmosphere that prevails at The "Harmony".
rationale: The review showcases a negative emotion as it describes the unfriendly atmosphere, hostile attitude, mistreatment of bands, and lack of trust towards customers at The Harmony Bar, making it clear that the overall experience is unpleasant and not worth the visit.

question:
This is where YELP gets odd - any idea the demographics for the other reviewers? 

As a neighborhood bar, yes you are expected to behave - and geez, not having easy tabs going and having to pay as you go may be a pain. But really?! there's a cash machine right next to the pool table. Do the owners have a right to close down when it's bar time, indeed. 

What a bunch of whinners!

Drinks are served well and timely. Food is good. Better than good - hot, made to order, and fresh. 

Kids are expected to behave (and ours have been reminded as have we - good for all). Do we go there for yummy, fun times with friends, yes! Are we grateful a local, privately owned business maintains it's unique flavors. Yes! 

Cheers to the Harmony!
rationale: The text mentions positive aspects such as good food, timely service, unique flavors, and fun times with friends, which outweigh the minor inconveniences mentioned earlier and overall evoke a sense of gratitude and enjoyment, thus representing positive emotion.

question: I see that all the negative reviews for this business have been flagged. To those thinking of trying this establishment: READ THE FLAGGED REVIEWS. You will have a far more balanced and accurate assessment.
rationale: The rationale for predicting negative emotion is that the text mentions negative reviews being flagged, which implies that the business might be trying to hide or manipulate negative feedback, potentially leading to a lack of transparency and trustworthiness.

question: Who is flagging down all the one-star reviews for The Harmony Bar? To anyone considering patronizing this establishment: read the flagged reviews.
rationale: The use of the phrase "one-star reviews" and the call to read them suggest a negative sentiment, implying that there may be significant issues or concerns with The Harmony Bar that potential patrons should be aware of before considering visiting it. Predicted emotion: Negative.

question: The service is absolutely horrible. The staff is rude and acts put out by your mere presence!
rationale: The text conveys negative emotion by describing the service as "absolutely horrible" and the staff as "rude" and "put out," which indicates dissatisfaction and frustration.

question:
Ventured in to the Harmony to celebrate the closing of my new house; turns out it's located about 1.5 blocks from my new pad, so I have a feeling I'll be getting more familiar with The Harmony.

What a cool place. Awesome bar, plenty of seating, live music (although with a cover charge...boo), great beer selection, and really solid food.

I tried the classic cheeseburger; patties were hand-formed and cooked to a perfect medium. Cheese curds came from a bag, but were some of the better ones I've ever tried. The house-made pub chips were excellent.

A small group of us ate and drank for a few hours; the total tab came to just over $60, which is an absolute bargain. Service was prompt and efficient, making for a great overall experience.

I'll be back (a lot)!

Oh, and check out the daily food specials - looks like they have some inventive and interesting options!
rationale: The text shows positive emotion because the reviewer had a great experience celebrating the closing of their new house at The Harmony, praising the cool atmosphere, awesome bar, good food, and efficient service, expressing eagerness to return in the future. Predicted emotion: Excitement.

question: The Harmony hours listed are dead wrong and they are open, not closed. Makes me wonder about the fact-checkers at yelp... do they have any?
rationale: The text conveys frustration and disappointment with the inaccurate information provided by the Harmony hours listed on Yelp, suggesting a negative emotion.

question: Beer selection is ok. Good room for seeing bands - sound was great. However, majority of the male staff here is unapologetically rude & disrespectful. Aging sports neanderthals that could care less that you're there.  \n\nDon't waste your time - spend your money at Mickey's Tavern or Crystal Corner instead.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the reviewer mentions that the male staff is rude and disrespectful, and recommends spending money at other places instead, indicating a strong dissatisfaction with the experience. Predicted emotion: Disappointment.

question:
It's a slow, but steady slide... 

Trying to count the total number of times I've been into the Harmony is futile; Yelp shows I have 16 check-ins, but I'd venture a guess that I check-in maybe once for every 2-3 visits.

Interacting with the bartenders, one would think each of my visits was my first. They don't seem to recall regulars, or if they do, they don't seem to care much. Not looking for any special treatment, but when I walk-in, sit down and say, "Hi, how's it going?" I'd hope for a bit of a reply other than a grunt or a "I'm so busy I couldn't possibly bother with a response" eye roll.

Food is continuing to slide; had a cheeseburger with fried onions last night... the dry bun overwhelmed the small, overcooked burger. A mound of fried onions delivered almost no extra flavor. Removed the bun and ate the burger solo.

Lake Louie Arena Premium is usually a fave of mine, but the one I had on Saturday (a few days earlier) tasted off - like the tap line was in need of a good cleaning.

I also wasn't allowed to start a tab; it was pay-as-I-go... so, when I ordered food and a beer, I had to pay (and tip). Need a refill? Pay again. Ugh.

There are so many great places in the area; I'll be visiting the other haunts. So sad.

Pub chips, though... yum.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the reviewer expresses disappointment with the declining quality of the food and drinks, lack of personal interaction from the bartenders, inconvenience of not being able to start a tab, and overall dissatisfaction leading to a decision to visit other establishments. Predicted sentiment: Disappointment.

question: Grade: D\n\nYeah, I order my martinis served on the rocks and in goblets... Duh.
rationale: This text shows a negative emotion as the reviewer is mocking the pretentiousness of ordering martinis in a particular way, which may come across as insincere or elitist, hence predicting a sentiment of sarcasm or disdain.

question: Great food and service.  Thanks.
rationale: The review mentions that the food was great and service was good, which typically indicate a positive experience and satisfaction with the overall dining experience, leading to a predicted positive sentiment.

question: My boyfriend and I went here because we had a $25 gift card and thought we'd get a cheap meal. Too bad TGI Fridays is incredibly overpriced. Maybe it's my own fault for choosing something besides a hamburger, but the pasta dinner I ordered was just awful. It was clearly a frozen meal they just heated up (I asked for no mushrooms and they told me it wasn't possible). I know many restaurants do this, but when I get a $50 bill for food I could have heated up at home it doesn't make me happy. Might as well go to Denny's. Same quality food, way better price.
rationale: The review mentions disappointment in the high prices and poor quality of the food, as well as feeling cheated for paying for something that could have been easily prepared at home, indicating a negative emotion of frustration.

question: Great food!  Prices are very reasonable for the amount you get.  Always very busy when I've been in, yet service is still great!
rationale: The review praises the quality of the food, the reasonable prices, and the great service, indicating a positive dining experience overall, thus predicting a positive sentiment.

question: Horrible food no flavor I went with my boyfriend he had gotten the boneless buffalo chicken wings and I got the shrimp and chicken pasta and we shared the Mac and cheese appetizer bites he had a couple of bites of my food and on the way home I started feeling sick when we got home he felt the same way and turns out he's got food poising I wouldn't go here again!
rationale: The text illustrates negative emotion as the reviewer had a bad experience with the food, got sick, and found out their boyfriend contracted food poisoning, leading them to declare they wouldn't visit the restaurant again. Predicted emotion: Disgust or Disappointment.

question: Started going here in college with my roommates when they had $5 burger Tuesdays.  Yeah its a chain but they seem to do it right. Menu has the standard fare,  with noticeable twists. They recently changed the recipes for some of their apps,  not for the better in my opinion,  but the green beean fries are my favorite.  Waiters are generally really good, and their stripes card gets you free chips and salsa,  as well as points for free food and desserts.  Vanilla bean cheesecake is a wonderful way to end your tgif dining!
rationale: This review demonstrates positive emotion as it highlights enjoyable experiences like $5 burger Tuesdays, unique menu twists, helpful waitstaff, and a pleasant dessert option, creating an overall favorable impression. Predicted emotion: Satisfaction.

question: Look - My wife likes this place so I go there now and again just to make her happy. I know it violates the bro code, but I have to sleep with her.\nMe personally, I could care less about Jack Daniels sauce (which is basically reconstituted dried onion and molasses with some other 'secret' ingredients.\nToo costly for what you get. 2 thumbs down.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the reviewer expresses dissatisfaction with the restaurant's quality, the cost of the food, and the fact that they are only visiting to please their wife, resulting in a negative rating of "2 thumbs down."

question:
Recently discovered this place and have come to really enjoy it.  Don't visit if you're expecting an upscale or hipster experience - this is a pure tavern with a limited beer selection, slightly wobbly barstools, low ceilings, limited space, and a seasoned crowd.

There are three beers on tap, including Spotted Cow.  The taps come in a 10oz mug; otherwise, there's a narrow range of canned and bottled beers - I usually go with a PBR.

The mixed drinks are excellent; the bartenders know their way around a highball glass.  They're also really nice folks - easy to chat with, interesting, and attentive.  

As others have mentioned, there's a decent jukebox (it's internet connected, so you can find nearly everything), and then of course there's the shuffleboard table.  Don't worry if you don't have a balanced/complete team - there will be someone that you can recruit from the bar to join.

Nothing really new to share here, other than to say don't hesitate to swing by here for a beverage or two.  As another reviewer said, "You can definitely do worse than Woody Anne's" and that's a statement I'd echo.  It's a bit of a haul for me to visit the place, but I'm always glad when I do.
rationale: The text showcases a positive emotion as it highlights the enjoyable atmosphere, excellent mixed drinks, friendly bartenders, and fun activities like the jukebox and shuffleboard table, ultimately recommending the place for a visit. Predicted emotion: happiness.

question:
A true, authentic dive in the most accurate sense of the word. There's neither pretense nor irony, either. This place has cheap-ish beer, decent shots, a great jukebox and patrons with good enough taste to make the right decisions when pumping money into it.

It's small and I'm pretty sure it's not air conditioned. However, this is a great down-to-earth place to while away some spare time. Nice people. As others have said, Don's a great bartender too.

Cash only, 'natch.
rationale: The text portrays a positive emotion because it highlights the authentic and unpretentious atmosphere of the bar, the good taste of the patrons, and the friendly service provided by the bartender, suggesting an enjoyable and laid-back experience. The use of phrases like "a great jukebox," "nice people," and "great bartender" convey a sense of satisfaction and contentment, leading to a predicted emotion of satisfaction.

question:
My first ever trip to Woody-Anne's involved a lady at the bar a) showing off a pic that proved ghosts exist cuz of an "orb" that is inexplicably present(?), b) flashing me her boobs for a drink that she never actually took me up on, and c) giving me an epicly gross (DRIPPING) wet willy, all in the span of Fleetwood Mac's "Landslide" which soundtracked the whole experience.

The evening ended with me and the bartender watching a M.A.S.H. rerun in what was by then an otherwise empty bar.

Needless to say, this is my New Favorite Place.
rationale: The text shows a negative emotion because it describes a series of uncomfortable and bizarre experiences involving a stranger at a bar, ending with watching a TV show in an empty bar, which may evoke feelings of awkwardness and unease.

question: We've taken our cars here several times and have never received anything but quality service. Each time I've genuinely felt as if they've provided us the best possible service and genuinely care about our satisfaction as customers.\n\nThe only reason I didn't give them 5 stars was because recently I went in for an alignment and they pointed out a repair that I needed and that they wouldn't be able to check the alignment until I got this repair. So, I went ahead and let them order the part, they fixed it perfectly, tested the alignment, found out the alignment was off and then told me because I drive a Cadillac, they don't have the proper tool to perform the alignment there and that I should take it to a Cadillac or GM dealership. That would've been nice to know before I authorized the repair, it is kind of inconvenient to take it to 2 different places. Not a huge deal though.
rationale: The review expresses a generally positive sentiment towards the quality of service provided, mentioning multiple instances of excellent customer care; however, the inconvenience caused by the lack of proper alignment tools for a Cadillac at the facility creates a mild negative emotion due to the unexpected inconvenience, leading to an overall slightly negative sentiment.

question:
I went in for an oil change and an inspection. i receive close to a thousand dollars in "recommendations." The next day, I decided to get the breaks serviced as they told me it was the most pressing issue with my car. After fixing my breaks they refused to put my tire on because they decided it was not road worthy, but for an additional 200 bucks they would fix it for me. 

Perhaps I would have been more understanding if :

1) This had been in the original inspection (it wasn't) 
2) I hadn't had the tire looked at on several other occasions including them (twice! Once several months ago and once during inspection) 
3) They hadn't decided for me what is and is not acceptable - (ask first then together we make choice).
4)They asked me to sign a new inspection ticket as if they had brought up wheels initially, smeared with capital letters and exclamations as if that would help send it back into the past. I found it so antagonizing that I decided to share the experience here.

It was shady business. it made me feel like they were trapping me into spending money that I did not have. There was a better way to express their concerns, if they were legitimate. In the end, I had someone else call on my behalf because I was so confused.

They get two stars because the person who called to inform me of the debacle tried to sound understanding and because my breaks seem to be in working order. 

With all this stress perhaps I should have gone to the dealer. Turns out they would have charged me less for my breaks.  (that almost never happens)  Just be careful and shop around.
rationale: The text showcases negative emotion as the reviewer expresses feelings of being trapped into spending money, frustration over the lack of transparency and feeling confused and antagonized by the shady business practices of the service provider, ultimately leading to the decision to share the experience as a warning to others. Predicted emotion: Frustration.

question: I brought my car in for an oil change and told them I had noticed that the front tires vibrated or shook at high speeds.  Left the car for them to check things out.  The called me to tell me I needed new tires, that there was uneven wear.  I told them to put them on and do a front end allignment.  When  I went to pick up the car, they told me it needed ball joints and tie rods, so they did not do the allignment (said it would have been a waste of money with the bad ball joints and tie rods).  When they discovered the problem with the tie rods and ball joints, they should have called me back.  Took it some place else to get a second opinion.  I was told Firestone should have never put new tires on the car when ball joints and tie rods were needed.  I will never go back to this Firestone.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the customer is dissatisfied with the service provided by Firestone due to not being informed about the additional necessary repairs and feeling that they were misled into purchasing new tires. Predicted emotion: Disappointment.

question: I'm a happy firestone customer.  After being ripped off by a small family owned auto repair shop in Madison, I was pretty leary of taking my car any where in this city.  \n\nThey've never pressured me to make repairs when I take my car in for an oil change or other minor services.  They have made me aware of things that will need repair or recommended services, but there's no pressure to fix it immediately.  I appreciate the heads up and I'm happy they respect my decision of not making repairs unless it's a safety issue.
rationale: The text expresses positive emotion because the customer had a negative experience with a previous auto repair shop but is now happy with Firestone's respectful and non-pressuring approach to repairs, making them feel valued and trusting in their decisions.

question: If you are looking to get a dentist phobia this place is for you.  The staff is great at making a person feel like scum of the earth for drinking coffee or juice because of the effects it has on teeth, even if the teeth are healthy.  You can relive getting lectured by your parents as they talk about the finer points of proper brushing from your vulnerable position strapped in a chair.  Few survive getting a filling but it is rumored that the experience is as pleasant as hearing fingernails on a chalkboard.  They are very talented in manhandling delicate gum tissue and patients are guaranteed a sore mouth for the rest of the day.  Customer service is second to none.  The office has evening appointments and if you are fortunate to schedule one you will be offered a once in a life time opportunity to come in earlier.  However if you are not able to get off of work and have to decline coming in early do not be surprised to get a call back from the receptionist informing you that your evening appointment is canceled because something unexpected has come up.  They like to provide service the old fashioned way so do not expect any state of the art technology.  Yes this place is highly recommended  for those looking for crap dentistry.
rationale: The review showcases a series of negative experiences and frustrations with the dental office, including feeling unwelcome and uncomfortable, as well as highlighting poor customer service and outdated technology, leading to a predicted sentiment of negativity.

question:
No one really likes the dentist.  Especially since I've gotten older and my teeth have gone to hell no matter what I do.  (Yes, lady--I do floss.  Yes, lady--I brush at least twice a day, sometimes more.)  It's one of those things we hate because it's annoying, it takes time out of our schedules, and it's often painful.  No matter how we brush our teeth, we are prone to cavities.

Midwest Dental isn't horrible.  I've had maybe five or six dentists in my life at this point, and I can probably say that of those that I've had, Midwest is the worst of them, but even still--they're not horrific.

Midwest tends to assign you a hygienist so you see the same person every time you go. This is the first dental practice I've visited where this is the case. Every other one I went to, the hygienist was whomever was available.  

My first hygienist at Midwest was a young girl, fresh out of her two-year program, I believe.  She was nice enough, and competent, but she was a kid.  She liked kid things.  My first visit, while she had hands in my mouth and I couldn't scream at her that I didn't give two flying figs, she told me all about what had been going on during "The Bachelorette" that season.  The second time, she asked me what I was reading (I had a book with me), and then told me all about how much she loved "Twilight." 

I was dreading a third uninformative visit with her, but she moved.  So, I was reassigned to a new hygienist.  Again:  A nice enough, competent hygienist, but not someone with whom I want to have a conversation. She still works there, so I won't go into too much detail in case she ever reads this.  She's a wonderful person, but I'm an introvert by nature. I don't want to make small talk.  I don't want to hear about her kids. I don't really tell people about my kids--why do I want to hear about yours, lady?

The hygienist is absolutely brutal with the dental floss.  She hammers that wax garrote up and down my teeth with all the subtlety of a teenage boy groping boobs for the first time.  

"Oh, your gums are bleeding.  You're not flossing enough."

Lady, I floss every friggin' day.  My gums don't bleed when I floss.  Maybe it's because you're trying to go THROUGH the frickin' tissue instead of along the tooth?  Don't even get me started on her skills with the violent metal pick.  She has cut me like Wolverine.

They also really like to indict you on anything you do food and drink-wise at this place.  "Your teeth show wear.  Are you drinking soda?"

Yeah, a can or two a day.  But I brush.

"YOU SHOULD NEVER DRINK SODA!  IN FACT, IF YOU LIVE IN A COUNTY WITH A SODA BOTTLING PLANT, YOU HAVE TO MOVE!  DON'T COME WITHIN TWO HUNDRED MILES OF A SODA!"

Geez, lady. Lighten up.  

"How much do you brush a day?"

At least twice.  Once in the morning before I leave for work, and again at night.  Sometimes I sneak another one in there sometimes.

"How many minutes, though?"

Two or three per session, plus flossing at night.

"YOU SHOULD BRUSH YOUR TEETH FOR THIRTY HOURS.  NEVER STOP BRUSHING.  YOU'RE NOT BRUSHING ENOUGH."

Well hell, lady...

They also like to sell you extra crap that you may or may not need.  "Here--here's a special paste you should rub on your gums.  It's $15.  Here's a special toothpaste. You can only get it here. It's $15.  If you need more, come back here and spend another $15.  Here's a rinse. It was made from elf urine. It's magic.  $22."

If my dental plan could be covered under another dentist that didn't involve a drive across Madison, I'd probably switch up and go there.  Unfortunately, I'm limited in my choices, so I'm stuck returning to Midwest Dental.

At least there's a Perkins right next door.  Right after I get my teeth done, I take a special pleasure in going into Perkins for a stack of flappys with extra syrup and a diet Coke.

"YOU SHOULD NEVER EAT SUGAR!  AND WHAT DID I SAY ABOUT SODA?"

Geez, lady...it's life. I'm going to live it.  Relax a little.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the author expresses frustration and annoyance with their experiences at the dentist, highlighting issues with the hygienists, aggressive dental care, judgmental attitudes, and the pressure to purchase unnecessary products, ultimately leading to a feeling of being stuck with limited options and a desire to indulge in treats despite dental advice.

question: Not happy at all with the prints this company did for us.  I would not recommend them to anyone.  Very unprofessional and they just did not care that I was unhappy.
rationale: The text expresses a negative sentiment by detailing dissatisfaction with the quality of service provided by the printing company, highlighting their unprofessionalism and indifference towards the customer's unhappiness.

question: Thysse Printing is the best! Their sales staff is friendly and helpful, the quality of their print jobs is unmatched and they always make sure you get your project on time and 100% to your satisfaction. Would recommend them to anyone looking for a printer that will make their life easier and that's coming from a graphic designer of ten years.
rationale: The text expresses positive emotion by highlighting the excellent customer service, high-quality products, and emphasis on customer satisfaction at Thysse Printing, which is further confirmed by the recommendation from a professional in the field, indicating a high level of trust and satisfaction.

question: I'm not a die hard BBQ fan nor do I normally spring for it when I'm hungry but after eating here I may change my tune.\nThe ribs are amzaing, the meat practically falls off the bone and is so tender!! The pulled pork sandwich is equally delicious and the serving size is more than generous. The sweet bisquits are a nice way to end the meal, served piping hot and covered in powdered sugar; although ordering them serperate is recommended as the baked beans and fries are a must have!!
rationale: The text is positive because it praises the quality and taste of the food, mentioning that the ribs are amazing, the pulled pork sandwich is delicious, and the serving size is generous, with a pleasant dessert option at the end, all of which could evoke a positive emotion of satisfaction or delight.

question: mmmm....eerrrr... this is not real barbeque.  The ribs don't taste bad, but they aren't cooked slow enough, because the meat doesn't fall off the bone and all the flavor comes from the sauce that's slathered on it, not the actual meat.  The turkey was a insult to the art of barbecuing -- it tasted like deli meat that had been sprayed with liquid smoke.
rationale: The review conveys negative emotion because the author is disappointed by the quality of the barbecue, describing the ribs as not meeting the expected standard of being cooked slow enough, and the turkey as tasting like deli meat sprayed with liquid smoke. The overall tone is critical and unsatisfied, indicating a negative sentiment.

question:
After hearing that this place was the bees knees from many friends and reviews, I decided to take a small group of friends and give it the test.  Afterwards I was impressed and absolutely full, but I wouldn't give it the BBQ crown.

I think most of the value here comes from its uniqueness.  Smoky Jon's sits in a small little log-cabin-style shack, and when you walk in you are witness to the plethora of awards they have received from their delicious BBQ fixins.  Soon, you'll discover their own personal sauce (which I hope you slather across your food), and a menu that has item descriptions which make you want to grow a second stomach.  Corn bread, beans, ribs, brisket, pulled pork, etc; all the delectable food you'd expect from a place like this.  I personally had ribs and brisket with corn bread, and I ate every last bite with no regrets.

Problem is, I've had some really good Barbecue in my life, and the overall taste of the food, while good, wasn't great in comparison.  Some of the places I've dined at in Kansas City, for instance, were a step up from this.  Even some of the dishes at Famous Daves could rival Smoky Jon's, although the ribs certainly could not.  

The rest of my party all had mixed responses.  My girlfriend didn't really care for what she ordered (I can't remember what it was, a sandwich of some sort), and several of them didn't like the smallishness of the place or the service.  The lady was OK, but she was behind the counter mostly and didn't do much to make us feel welcome.  When we walked in we were all really excited to be there and try it, and she was just kind of "meh."  Also, the location is probably the least desirable of any restaurant I've been to in Madison, but that's more relative to where you live or how you feel about certain neighborhoods.

Overall, worth a try and probably one of the better BBQs as far as Madison goes.  While it doesn't get the full star ride from me, I can see why others give it high praise.
rationale: The review leans more towards negative emotion because although the food was good, it did not meet the high expectations set by prior reviews and the reviewer found other barbecue places to be superior. Additionally, mixed responses from the reviewer's friends, including his girlfriend not liking her dish and the lackluster service, also contribute to the negative sentiment predicted.

question: This place is running on the fact that there really is no good BBQ in Madison. And Smoky Jon, if that is his real name, may have won a lot of awards, but he is not selling that winning BBQ at this location.\n\nI got off a plane starving after a long business weekend and I could not eat the ribs that were served because the tips were burnt and more like chewing tobacco than ribs. I wouldn't mention the sides because that is not why you go to these places, but Jon you need to get off the beach in Cancun and work on these recipes, they ST-I-N-K.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion because it criticizes the quality of the BBQ served at the restaurant, emphasizing that the ribs were burnt and inedible, suggesting a disappointment with the dining experience.

question:
Smoky Jon's is some of the best BBQ I've had in Madison.  However, I haven't tried many places, so that's not saying much.  I really enjoy the ribs and the pork shoulder sandwich.  The brisket is good as well.  I have found all the barbecued menu items to be flavorful and tender.  The burgers aren't that good, however; they're overdone and greasy.

The sides also leave something to be desired.  I've never had a bad side dish, but I've only really been impressed by the fried biscuits.  The mashed potatoes are runner-up.  The pasta salad and potato salad are both well below average.

Service at Smoky Jon's is both quick and friendly.  Employees will remember you, which is always nice.  The prices are good.  The location is a little iffy, though; the parking lot is too small and the building itself can feel cramped.

All problems aside, I will keep coming here for the delicious BBQ.
rationale: The review mentions that the BBQ at Smoky Jon's is some of the best, with flavorful and tender menu items, quick and friendly service, good prices, and despite some issues like mediocre sides, overdone burgers, and a cramped location, the reviewer will continue to dine there, indicating an overall positive sentiment.

question: I've had BBQ all over the country but the sauce here is my kind of flavor. The meat is so tender and juicy it hardly needs sauce, but the sauce is so good I have to get an extra cup on the side! All the sides are tasty so you can't go wrong there.
rationale: This text shows positive emotion because the reviewer expresses satisfaction and enthusiasm about the BBQ sauce flavor, the tenderness and juiciness of the meat, and the tastiness of the sides, indicating a positive dining experience. Predicted emotion: Happiness.

question:
BBQ Sauce is spectacular.  But the restaurant is horrible -- uncomfortable dining room, prices way too high to be a no-service, order at the counter place, sides are minuscule in tiny cups, and there's no bar, not even beer!  What's BBQ without beer to go with it?  

Prices are way over the top for Madison.

Stop by for some takeout pulled pork, or buy a bottle of exceptional BBQ sauce and do it yourself at home.
rationale: The text expresses negative emotion as it criticizes multiple aspects of the restaurant, such as uncomfortable dining room, high prices, minimal sides, lack of a bar, and high prices, without offering any positive feedback. Therefore, the predicted emotion is disappointment.

question:
I take my BBQ seriously and because of that I researched on-line via Yelp and other sites various reviews of BBQ places in Madison, finally deciding on Smoky Jon's No 1 B-B-Q.  Clearly the ribs have been highly reviewed so I actually went for the full slab.  Then it was a choice between the chopped pork sandwich and the brisket sandwich, I went for the pork sandwich from my fond memories of the same in Alabama.  Ordering over the phone, everything seemed to go well.  I then arrived about a half hour later.  There was 1 person in front of me who paid and was getting ready to leave when they brought my order to the counter and it was clearly wrong.  They had given my order to the man before me and I had his.  Apparently we both had the same first name.  Now this I was not perturbed by and was okay with, it was what followed that made me give this place 1 star.  So the counter lady tells me she'll take care of me first before resolving his issue, great!  So she charges my card for 64.66 which was clearly way more than I should have paid for 1 slab dinner and 1 pork sandwich + 1 side of fried dough.  Should have been 1/2 that.  I told her and she couldn't understand what I was talking about, I had to over-explain what I ordered and finally got through to her.  She took the bag back to the kitchen area saying some guy would have to deal with fixing this problem.  Now I was getting irritated.  She refunds me around 32 bucks in cash to make up for the overcharge.  I get a new bag of food and am finally done with the transaction, took about 15 mins to resolve.  Fine, I was happy in knowing I had a great dinner to enjoy soon.

So I come back and begin with the ribs, 1/2 a slab.  From the first taste I was not impressed.  I've had better ribs all over the country from Los Angeles to Alabama to Texas and Chicago.  Seriously?  This place has won all kinds of awards, I don't get it.  Almost every other place I've eaten ribs in my 40+ years of life has been better than this place.  The "sugar-fried" biscuits are nothing with nothing, you can get better donuts nearly anywhere, seriously (again).  The fries dipped in the BBQ sauce were the best part by far.  The corn was pretty good too, but still a little over the top on the taste, hard to describe.  So after being disappointed, I checked out the pork sandwich, and oddly enough there were 3 small containers with the sandwich, and somehow it didn't look like pork either.  I examined further, it was chicken, yet another screw-up with my order, wow!  And I ordered fries and mashed potatoes, neither of which was included.  Instead I found off-the-shelf beans, apple sauce (why?) which is not homemade, just spooned out of the jar, and the third container was BBQ sauce, which I didn't need since I bought a whole bottle.  So the other part of my order was completely wrong in every respect.  And note, the chicken was not anything to write home about either.  I drove to the other side of Madison, which was a fairly pleasant 1/2 hour drive, paid around 33 bucks for a very disappointing experience.

I strongly recommend NOT going to this place, unless you like to take risks, maybe you'll like what you find, I know that if this is the best in Madison, I'll have to go elsewhere in the world to find good BBQ.

Oh well...
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the reviewer had a series of negative experiences from a mix-up with the order to disappointment with the food quality, resulting in an overall unsatisfactory dining experience. Predicted emotion: disappointment. The reviewer clearly expected more from the highly rated BBQ place, but the series of mix-ups and subpar food left them feeling let down and dissatisfied, leading to their strong recommendation to avoid the establishment.

question:
Great BBQ!
It's a little out of the way, but worth the journey if you're looking for decent BBQ.
I don't remember seeing any highchairs.  We ended up bringing in our stroller for our daughter to sit in.
While you have to order your food at the counter, there is a wait staff that will bring your food to you and refill your drinks.
No alcoholic beverages... (that's why 4 stars).
rationale: The text shows positive emotion because it praises the BBQ as great and worth the journey, highlights the presence of helpful wait staff, and only slightly deducts a star for the absence of alcoholic beverages, overall indicating a mostly positive experience. Predicted sentiment: Positive.

question: 1/2 slab and pork shoulder with sugar fried biscuits and garlic mashed potatoes. We need one of these in Philadelphia. The BBQ was so tender and flavorful.  Sides were good but not as amazing as the meat. Will definitely be back to try the brisket before I head back east. The restaurant itself is small and cramped but the food is worth it.
rationale: The text expresses positive emotion because the reviewer enjoyed the tender and flavorful BBQ, and is keen to return to try more dishes despite the cramped restaurant setting, suggesting overall satisfaction with the experience. Predicted sentiment: Positive emotion.

question:
This is pretty good bbq for madison, but that doesn't say that much.
I haven't been everywhere in town, but honestly I think Famous Dave's is better.

Basically its decent food, but if you've had real bbq somewhere like memphis, kansas city, st. louis, or anywhere south of wisconsin,  you will be disappointed.
rationale: The text mentions that the BBQ in Madison is decent, but not as good as BBQ from other places like Memphis, Kansas City, or St. Louis, which suggests disappointment, leading to a prediction of negative emotion.

question: Well this is a tough one. A few years back, I stopped going to SJ'sbecause I was sick of getting rubbery non tender ribs. In the 90's, you could always count on getting the BEST ribs around, EVERY time. I think that the fact that Jon worked there then made the difference. Since he retired, I dont know what happened exactly? However, recently I stopped in for a shoulder platter, and everything was great, so go figure. The sauce is fantastic, and when done well, this place is something special.
rationale: The text displays mixed emotions - disappointment with the decline in quality of the ribs in the past, but optimism and satisfaction with the recent positive dining experience. Predicted sentiment: Mixed emotions.

question: I love this place! I had them cater my wedding, had the Pig up and Go package delivered and set up. We had BBQ pork, beef, and turkey along with sides. The only complaint I had was the turkey, I had assumed (and I know you should never assume!) it would be fresh, shredded turkey like the the pork and beef, but it was the processed, sliced turkey breast meat chopped up. That set aside, everything was delivered as scheduled, the employee who dropped the food off was very courteous and made sure to give us clear instructions on everything. We also visited here prior to our wedding and I shared the whole rack of ribs with my daughter and my husband had gotten the rotisserie chicken, the helpings were huge, the ribs were thick with meat and we did not leave hungry! Way better than Famous Dave's ribs
rationale: The text expresses positive emotion because it highlights the enjoyable experience of having the place cater their wedding, positive interactions with the employees, and delicious food with generous portions, outweighing the minor disappointment with the turkey. The overall glowing review and comparison to a well-known rib place indicate a positive sentiment.

question:
The ribs were the best I have ever had. The BBQ sauce is probably the best I have had. And everything is very smokey flavored, which, for me, is a very good thing. I had a chance to also try the chicken (awesome) and brisket (decent, but not amazing). 

For the sides, I got corn and the French fries. This was surprising for me but the fries were average and the corn was unbelievable. I pretty much assume corn is corn, but not here. 

Finally, I liked the style of the place. It is a hole in the wall without man tables. I like that and recommend everyone to head there.
rationale: The positive sentiment in the review is evident as the author praises the ribs, BBQ sauce, chicken, and corn, highlighting the flavors and quality of the food. The author also appreciates the unique style of the restaurant, recommending it to others, which further indicates a positive experience. Predicted emotion: Satisfaction.

question: The ribs, you must try them! My major mistake was getting a 1/3 slab.
rationale: The text mentions excitement over the ribs, recommending them to try, but expresses regret over only getting a small portion, leading to a sense of disappointment or negativity. Predicted emotion: Negative.

question:
A real gem!  I don't get to Madison often but I am sure that if the next trip is near a meal time I know where I'll stop, Smoky Jon's. Recently our party of three each had a different entree, one that the host suggested after learning we were newby's. He guaranteed that we would love our choices and we all did.

The BBQ pork sandwich was generous, the pork was extremely tender, cooked just right (not dried out or raw) had a smokey tang that makes it so special. The ribs were cooked to perfection and tender meat nearly fell off each bone.Their sauce is mild and OK but I was surprised by the limited choices in that area.

They offer several sides and the ones we sampled were all above par. The place is adorned with "Best Of" plaques and I can see why.
rationale: The review describes the dining experience at Smoky Jon's in a very positive light, highlighting the generous portions, delicious entrees, perfection in cooking, and high-quality sides, which overall creates a positive and satisfied sentiment.

question:
RIBS RIBS RIBS! I like me some niceeee slab of ribs, drizzled in a tangy, but slightly sweet BBQ sauce. Smoky Jon's definitely delivered!! They held  true to their many awards (nicely displayed next to their register) and I was more than content once I finished eating.

The ribs themselves were just ordinary- pretty juicy, but nothing to blow my mind. What I found amazing was the sauce and the sides!!! The corn was deliciousss, especially all dressed up in their special seasoning. The garlic mashed potatoes tasted just like the ones I usually make at home, which are pretttty darn amazing- if I should say so myself.

One downfall was that there is a $4.00 plate splitting fee (BOOOOO!). I really wanted to try the 1/2 slab + sandwich + sides combo (only like 2 bucks more than just 1/2 slab) but I knew I couldn't finish it by myself... and it just wouldnt be worth it to pay $4.00 more to share it with a friend. Hmm... or maybe, next time don't be as dumb as me and say out loud you want to share.... sneakily share it at the table!!

Anyways, Smoky Jon's was a great farewell from Madison meal for me, leaving me nice and full, the perfect prep for a long flight back to Los Angeles. 
I'd give it a solid 4 stars.
rationale: This review shows positive emotion as the reviewer enjoyed the ribs, praised the sauce and sides, and overall had a satisfying experience despite the minor issue with the plate splitting fee. Predicted emotion: satisfaction.

question: Tucked away on the north side of Madison. I've driven past it thousands of times but went there yesterday on a recommendation from a friend of mine who knows his BBQ. Soooooo gooooooood. I had the pork shoulder sandwich. The baked beans were pure flavor country. I wish everything I ate from here on out could be drizzled in that BBQ sauce. Service was pretty quick and the prices were not bad either. I'll be coming back again.
rationale: The text praises the quality of the food at the restaurant, expressing excitement and satisfaction with phrases like "Soooooo goooooood" and "pure flavor country," which indicates a positive sentiment.

question:
First things first: the house BBQ sauce is fabulous. I love that it isn't just the regular brown house made goop that most BBQ joints serve. You can actually see and taste all the different spices/herbs!! Like I said, fabulous. 

I went with the smoked chopped pork shoulder sandwich platter and two sides: the potato salad and the corn. If you (like me) choose to order the corn to ease your conscience (after all, it is a vegetable, right?)...do not be fooled. The corn is puuuure buttery goodness. The potato salad is also delicious! Truly, the perfect complement to the sandwich. Creamy, no skin, no dill, just the way I like my potato salads. :9

At $8.45, the sandwich platters are very reasonably priced for the quantity of food you get. The takeout service is super quick as well - I think I got my food within 2-3 minutes of placing my order. Otherwise, Smoky Jon's seems like a fun place to dine in as well (lots of exposed wooden paneling and checkered tablecloths). You'll probably want to limit your party to a group of 4 or less though, the seating is limited!

Yelp recommendations for what to order as a first-timer to Smoky Jon's are on point. I can't wait to be back to try the ribs!!

Tip: their parking lot is tiny and shared with the bar next door, so don't expect to find any open spaces around lunch or dinner time. You'll have better luck parking on one of the residential streets behind the joint.
rationale: The text shows positive emotion because the reviewer raves about the delicious BBQ sauce, flavorful dishes, reasonable prices, quick service, cozy ambiance, and helpful Yelp recommendations, ultimately expressing excitement and anticipation to return, which predicts a positive sentiment.

question:
Was driving by Madison and thought we'd get some BBQ.  I had the spicy chicken, which was just a chicken breast on a bun, with sauce on the side.  That was it, not even a big chicken breast? 

My wife had the turkey sandwich, which didn't appear to be anything special either.  It looked like it was from a grocery store.

Kids liked the burger and brats.

What I didn't like was the prices, sandwich platters were $8.45 each and drinks were $1.99 each.  Wasted my money on these as they don't give you a drink you can take with you and it's a plastic cup.  

What I did like was the sides, except for the one order of fried biscuit, which was raw in the middle.  Threw them out.

Last, I've never been to a BBQ place with no sauces on the table and only one served with the order.  I liked the sauce, but with all of the awards on the wall, they should offer a few options. 

Should have gotten the pulled pork.
rationale: The text expresses negative emotion as it mentions disappointment with the food, high prices, raw biscuit sides, and lack of sauce options, ultimately regretting the choice made and suggesting an alternative option. Predicted emotion: Disappointment.

question:
I had to make sure I didn't leave any sauce on my fingers prior to typing this. Wait, did I? Nope, clean. Most likely because I licked them clean from the baller sauce that is on this BBQ. The sauce has a great consistency to it and it clings nicely to the meat. 

I went with the sig-other and between the two of us, we had the pork shoulder sandwich,  brisket, and ribs. I think we both went with fries and the Cole-slaw for our sides. They were fine. Sides are sides. I realllllllly wish there would have been corn bread. Something doesn't right within me if there is no corn bread to accompany BBQ. I was sad when I found out there was no cornbread.

But then I was happy again the moment I was able to put that delicious pig in my mouth. The ribs were ribs. The brisket and the pork shoulder was where it was at for me, but really, I think you can slap that sauce on cardboard and it would be delicious.

I'm a west-sider so coming out here is a haul. A worth while haul. Be prepared to wait though; the dining room is small.  They did get out food out to us really quickly, but if we would have come 15 minutes later we would have had to wait in a long line to place our order, and then would have had no where to sit. 

Oh, and if I wasn't such a bottomless pit, there would have been plenty of leftovers as the portions are plentiful. I definitely did not leave hungry.
rationale: The text shows positive emotion because the reviewer expresses enjoyment and satisfaction with the food, despite a minor disappointment about the lack of cornbread; the overall tone is enthusiastic and content. Predicted emotion: Satisfaction.

question: ok food but most of it is frozen or canned and the ribs gave me the shits.
rationale: The text expresses negative emotion because the food is described as being mostly frozen or canned, and the fact that the ribs caused stomach problems implies a negative experience, leading to a predicted emotion of disgust or dissatisfaction.

question: I gave myself an hour to eat dining in before I have to catch a plane. I ordered. I waited 45 minutes. It seemed busy and I was stupid enough to keep waiting even though I see the guy who ordered before me get his and leave 20 minutes in. I didn't have anymore time and asked them to check my order. Nope, the ticket was lost.\n\nI was so hungry and so sad that I couldn't get any ribs. In the state of chaos that the kitchen and staff was in, there was no way they were gonna rush the order out in time even for to-go. I had to get a refund and speed to the airport. For what it's worth I don't think the 1 woman on wait staff was to blame. The owner really threw her under the bus by understaffing on a busy night. There's so many people, so many orders. There was another girl just taking orders. Just standing and waiting, while the other woman ran back and forth with bags and bags of food. What kind of restaurant is this? It's such a weird sight in a restaurant: one girl running another girl standing.  But at least I know she put my ticket into the kitchen. Someone fucked up in the kitchen; someone threw away my ticket. I will not be coming back and will not be sending any friends and family here either. For all the awards the place gets and all its years of being in business, I wish it just wasn't so amateur at being a restaurant.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as it describes a frustrating and disappointing dining experience due to long wait times, a lost order, chaos in the kitchen, and poor staffing decisions, leading to hunger and sadness, ultimately resulting in a decision to not return or recommend the restaurant to others.

question: The ribs are the best BBQ in Madison by far and have never disappointed in many visits. The rest of the menu is inconsequential -- trust me, just get the ribs.
rationale: The review is positive because it highlights the ribs as the best BBQ in Madison, never disappointing in many visits, and recommends them over the rest of the menu, showcasing a high level of satisfaction and confidence in the quality of the food. Predicted sentiment: Positive.

question: Damn good barbeque. Possibly the best I've had in Madison if I'm looking for something rich that will definitely fill you up and leave you feeling guilty. The ribs are top notch and the sauce is just right. Meat falls right off the bone and the sides are adequate. Just wish they had a spicy variant of some of their items. The interior goes great with the food; lots of vintage Americana items and newspaper cutouts of stunning reviews of the food. The service is very friendly, always willing to help you make up your mind about menu choices. The wait isn't very long for an entr\u00e9e and that's valuable. A friend I came with had the pulled pork burger and praised it greatly. \nThe food really lives up to its record-setting reputation. I'll be back in moderation so as not to clog my pipes up.
rationale: The text showcases positive emotion as the reviewer emphasizes the delicious food, friendly service, short wait times, and the vintage Americana ambiance, indicating an overall satisfying dining experience. Predicted emotion: satisfaction.

question:
I had lunch at Smoky Jon's on my first day in Madison.  I had seen stellar reviews, claiming it was the best BBQ in Madison.  Unfortunately, I was disappointed.

I ordered the brisket sandwich meal with fries and a side salad.  The fries were the best thing on the plate (maybe it's because I don't have fries very often), but these fries were just okay.  The salad was just bagged romaine lettuce with dressing in a packet.  I know that brisket can be a little fatty, but my brisket was almost as much fat as meat.  The brisket had soaked through the bottom side of my bun, so I ate it - or half of it - with a fork.

I assume Smoky Jon's had an off-day when I was there because they really get great user reviews.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the author was disappointed with their experience at Smoky Jon's, finding the food mediocre and the brisket overly fatty, despite high user reviews suggesting otherwise. Predicted emotion: Disappointment.

question: Awesome!! Can't believe i drove by it a million times and never went. Best ribs!!
rationale: This text shows positive emotion as the speaker is expressing excitement and satisfaction after finally trying the ribs and enjoying them, indicating a positive experience overall.

question: The best!  They have been around a long time and have thrived when other rib places come and go. I make the long trip across town when I need a half-slab.
rationale: The review indicates that the rib place is considered "the best" and long-lasting, which suggests the reviewer has a strong positive emotional connection, likely due to consistently good food and service, leading to a positive sentiment of satisfaction or happiness.

question: This has been on my radar for a while. See the pictures. First off this is important, when you walk in you smell smoke so I knew it was going to be good. Very woody and tons of awards and plaques etc. Thy were not as smokey as I wanted and boldly came sauced. They were fall off the bone and had that pink smoke ring on the inside. I had the half rack with beans and potato salad. The ribs were pretty good and I really liked the sauce and bought a bottle. The beans were nothing special and the potato salad was average. The beans would be great if they were smoked and hade little bits of meat in them. Sides are usually not the star and this was the case. The ribs are worth going for, my friends said this was there new BBQ place for them and they will be black. One person said the brisket sandwich was really good. Over all this is a solid BBQ rib place. Two thumbs up
rationale: The review describes a positive experience of visiting a BBQ rib place with ribs that were praised for being fall off the bone with a nice smoke ring. The reviewer also appreciated the sauce and even purchased a bottle, indicating overall satisfaction with the food. This positive feedback and the mention of friends identifying the restaurant as their new BBQ place suggest a positive sentiment of enjoyment and satisfaction.

question: Great rub on the ribs. Little to spicy sauce but, it was tasty. Mac 'n cheese is ok. Pork and brisket sandwichs are AWESOME. Definitely coming back!!!
rationale: This text demonstrates positive emotion because the reviewer praises the taste of the ribs, the awesomeness of the pork and brisket sandwiches, and expresses excitement about returning, indicating satisfaction and enjoyment. Predicted emotion: Positive.

question: Well, I read the reviews and thought this would be impressive. Nothing could be farther from the truth! The dude at the counter appeared annoyed that we interrupted him yesterday, the portions on the beans and potato salad were miniscule (I was unaware that you could even serve beans and potato salad in a cup designed for condiments, but lo and behold, here it was--- 3 bites later and both were history). We had the pulled pork sandwiches, and I make better at home. The bbq sauce was good, but that was about it. We don't plan on coming back ever, especially not for $23.00 for 2 people... But, we did fill up on gelato at the mall about 20 minutes later as we were still hungry when we left. I'm wondering where in the heck the other folks on here ate, because this wasn't at all the same experience they had.
rationale: The text shows negative emotion as the reviewer expresses disappointment with the food portion, quality, and overall experience, and states they do not plan on returning. Predicted sentiment: Disappointment.

question:
This local BBQ icon was on our list of dining destinations when Santi and I were planning our trip to Madison. Located nearby the airport, the well-lit, wooded interior starts with a pathway that leads to the large overhead menu, the ordering counter, and the dining area. Adding to the décor are the statewide accolades all around the walls. On this evening, the casual atmosphere happened to be unexpectedly subdued, quite unlike the other BBQ restaurants I've visited.
